passages.40:5: Many things, O Yahweh my God, you have done-- your wonderful deeds and your thoughts toward us. There is none to compare with you. If I [tried to] proclaim and tell [of them], they would be too numerous to count.
passages.40:6: A sacrifice and offering you do not desire. {My ears you have opened}.<note: Literally "Ears you have dug for me."> Burnt offering and sin offering you have not demanded.
passages.40:7: Then I said, "Look, I come. In [the] scroll of [the] book it is written concerning me:
passages.40:8: 'I delight to do your will, O my God, and your law [is] {deep within me}.'"<note: Literally "in the midst of my intestines">
passages.40:9: I have brought good tidings [of] righteousness in the great congregation. Look, I have not shut my lips. O Yahweh, {you surely know that}.<note: Literally "you, you know">
passages.40:10: Your righteousness I have not hidden in the midst of my heart. I have spoken of your faithfulness and your salvation. I have not concealed your loyal love or your faithfulness from [the] great congregation.
passages.40:11: As for you, O Yahweh, do not withhold your mercies from me. Let your loyal love and your faithfulness continually preserve me.
passages.40:12: For evils without number have encompassed me. My iniquities have overtaken me, so that I am not able to see. They are more than the hairs of my head, and my heart fails me.
passages.40:13: Be pleased, O Yahweh, to deliver me. O Yahweh, hurry to help me.
passages.40:14: Let them be shamed and abashed altogether who seek to take away my life.<note: Or "soul"> Let them be repulsed and humiliated [who] desire my harm.
passages.40:15: Let them be appalled because of their shame, those who say to me, "Aha! Aha!"
passages.40:16: Let them rejoice and be glad in you, all those who seek you. Let them say continually, "Yahweh is great!" --those who love your salvation.
passages.40:17: But I [am] poor and needy. Let my Lord consider me. You [are] my help and my deliverer. O my God, do not delay.
passages.41:title: For the [music] director. A psalm of David.<note: The Hebrew Bible counts the superscription as the first verse of the psalm; the English verse number is reduced by one>
passages.41:1: Blessed [is the one who] has regard for [the] poor; in [the] day of disaster, Yahweh delivers him.
passages.41:2: Yahweh protects him and keeps him alive; he is blessed in the land, and you do not give him into the will<note: Hebrew "soul"> of his enemies.
passages.41:3: Yahweh sustains him on [his] sick bed. In his illness, you {restore to health}.<note: Literally "his every bed you change">
passages.41:4: As for me, I said, "O Yahweh, be gracious [to] me. Heal me,<note: Or "my soul"> for I have sinned against you."
passages.41:5: My enemies speak evil about me, "When will he die and his name perish?"
passages.41:6: And when one comes to see [me], he speaks falsely; his heart gathers disaster for itself. He goes out to the street; he speaks.
passages.41:7: All who hate me speak together against me. Against me they assume the {worst}<note: Literally "evil"> for me:
passages.41:8: "A ruinous thing is poured out on him, and [now] that he lies down, he will not rise up again."
passages.41:9: Even {my close friend},<note: Literally "the man of my peace"> whom I trusted, [who] ate my bread, has lifted [his] heel against me.
passages.41:10: But you, O Yahweh, be gracious to me and raise me up that I may repay them.
passages.41:11: By this I know that you delight in me: because my enemy has not shouted in triumph over me.
passages.41:12: As for me, you have upheld me in my integrity, and you have set me in your presence forever.
passages.41:13: Blessed [be] Yahweh, the God of Israel, from everlasting to everlasting. Amen and Amen.
passages.42:title: For the [music] director. A maskil of the sons of Korah.<note: The Hebrew Bible counts the superscription as the first verse of the psalm; the English verse number is reduced by one>
passages.42:1: As a deer longs for streams of water, so my soul longs for you, O God.
passages.42:2: My soul thirsts for God, for [the] living God. When shall I come and appear before God?<note: Some Hebrew manuscripts and versions read "and see the face of God?">
passages.42:3: My tears have been my food day and night, while [they] say to me all day [long], "Where [is] your God?"
passages.42:4: These I remember and I pour out my soul within me: that I would go with the multitude; I led them [in procession] to the house<note: Or "temple"> of God, with a voice of rejoicing and thanksgiving, a crowd celebrating a festival.
passages.42:5: Why are you {in despair},<note: Literally "bowed down"> O my soul, and disturbed within me? Hope in God, because I will again praise him, [for] the salvation of his presence.
passages.42:6: O my God, within me my soul is {in despair};<note: Literally "bowed down"> therefore I remember you from the land of Jordan and the heights of Hermon, from the mountain of Mizar.
passages.42:7: Deep [is] calling to deep at<note: Or "to"> the thunder of your waterfalls. All your breakers and your waves have passed over me.
passages.42:8: By day Yahweh commands his loyal love, and in the night his song [is] with me, a prayer to the God of my life.
passages.42:9: I say to God, my rock, "Why have you forgotten me? Why must I walk about mourning because of [the] oppression of [the] enemy?"
passages.42:10: [As] with a shattering in my bones my oppressors taunt me, while they say to me {all day},<note: Literally "all the day"> "Where [is] your God?"
passages.42:11: Why are you {in despair},<note: Literally "bowed down"> O my soul? And why are you disturbed within me? Hope in God, because I shall again praise him, {my salvation}<note: Literally "the salvation of my face"> and my God.
passages.43:1: Judge me, O God, and plead my case against<note: Or "because of"> an unfaithful<note: Or "disloyal"> nation. From a man of deceit and wickedness rescue me,
passages.43:2: because you [are] the God of my refuge. Why have you rejected me? Why must I go about mourning because of [the] oppression of [the] enemy?
passages.43:3: Send your light and your truth; they shall lead<note: Or "let them lead"> me. They shall bring me to {your holy mountain}<note: Literally "the mountain of your holiness"> and to your dwelling places.
passages.43:4: Then<note: Or "And"> I will go to the altar of God, to God, {my surpassing joy},<note: Literally "the joy of my gladness"> and I will praise you with lyre, O God, my God.
passages.43:5: Why are you {in despair},<note: Literally "bowed down"> O my soul? And why are you disturbed within me? Hope in God, because I will again praise him, {my salvation}<note: Hebrew "the salvation of my face"> and my God.
passages.44:title: For the [music] director. Of the sons of Korah. A maskil.<note: The Hebrew Bible counts the superscription as the first verse of the psalm; the English verse number is reduced by one>
passages.44:1: O God, we have heard with our ears; our ancestors<note: Or "fathers"> have told us of work you worked in their days, in days of old.
passages.44:2: You [with] your hand drove out the nations, but them<note: That is, Israel> you planted. You harmed [the] peoples, but them<note: That is, Israel> you let spread out.
passages.44:3: For not with their sword did they possess [the] land, and their arm did not give them victory. Rather [it was] your right hand and your arm and the light of your presence, because you delighted in them.
passages.44:4: You are my king, O God. Command<note: Or "who commands," see LXX> victories for Jacob.
passages.44:5: By you we push down our enemies; by your name we tread down those who rise up against us.
passages.44:6: For I do not trust my bow, and my sword cannot give me victory.
passages.44:7: Rather you have saved us from our enemies,<note: Or "made us victorious over our enemies"> and have humiliated those who hate us.
passages.44:8: In God we boast all the day, and we will give thanks [to] your name forever. Selah
passages.44:9: Surely you have rejected and disgraced us, and have not gone out with our armies.
passages.44:10: You have caused us to pull back from [the] enemy, and [so] those who hate us have plundered for themselves.
passages.44:11: You have given us as sheep [for] food, and among the nations you have scattered us.
passages.44:12: You have sold your people {cheaply},<note: Literally "for [what is] not wealth"> and did not profit by their price.
passages.44:13: You have made us a taunt to our neighbors, a derision and a scorn to those around us.
passages.44:14: You have made us a byword among the nations, a shaking of [the] head among [the] peoples.
passages.44:15: {All day long}<note: Literally "All of the day"> my disgrace [is] before me, and the shame of my face covers me,
passages.44:16: because of [the] voice of [the] taunter and [the] reviler, because of [the] enemy and [the] avenger.
passages.44:17: All this has befallen us, though we have not forgotten you, and we have not been false to your covenant.
passages.44:18: Our heart has not turned back, and our steps have [not] turned aside from your way.
passages.44:19: But you have crushed us in a place of jackals, and have covered us with deep shadow.
passages.44:20: If we had forgotten the name of our God, or had spread out our hands [in prayer] to a foreign god,
passages.44:21: would not God discover this, for he knows [the] secrets of [the] heart?
passages.44:22: Rather, on account of you we are killed {all day long};<note: Literally "all of the day"> we are accounted as sheep for slaughter.
passages.44:23: Wake up! Why do you sleep, O Lord? Awake! Do not reject forever.
passages.44:24: Why do you hide your face? [Have] you forgotten our misery and our oppression?
passages.44:25: For our soul is bowed down to the dust. Our {body}<note: Literally "belly"> clings to the ground.
passages.44:26: Rise up! [Be a] help for us, and redeem us for the sake of your loyal love.
passages.45:title: For the [music] director; according to [The] Lilies. Of the sons of Korah. A maskil. A song of love.<note: The Hebrew Bible counts the superscription as the first verse of the psalm; the English verse number is reduced by one>
passages.45:1: My heart is moved [with] a good word; I recite my {compositions}<note: Literally "works," that is, the song he has composed> to [the] king. My tongue [is the] pen [of] a skilled scribe.
passages.45:2: You are [the most] handsome of [the] sons of humankind; grace is poured out on your lips; therefore God has blessed you forever.
passages.45:3: Gird your sword on [your] thigh, O mighty one, [in] your splendor and your majesty.
passages.45:4: And [in] your majesty {ride victoriously},<note: Literally "Succeed! Ride!"> because of truth and humility [and] righteousness. And let your right hand teach you awesome deeds.
passages.45:5: Your arrows [are] sharp; peoples fall under you in the midst of the king's enemies.
passages.45:6: Your throne, O God, [is] forever and ever. A scepter of uprightness [is] the scepter of your kingdom.
passages.45:7: You love righteousness and hate wickedness. Therefore God, your God, has anointed you from among your companions [with] festive oil.
passages.45:8: All your robes [are scented with] myrrh and aloes [and] cassia. From palaces of ivory stringed instruments gladden you.
passages.45:9: Kings' daughters [are] among your noble ladies. The queen stands at your right hand in gold of Ophir.
passages.45:10: Hear, O daughter, and {discern}<note: Literally "see"> and incline your ear, and forget your people and your father's house.
passages.45:11: Let the king desire your beauty.<note: Or "Should the king desire ... then bow down ..."> Because he [is] your lord, therefore<note: Hebrew "and"> bow down to him.
passages.45:12: Even the daughter of Tyre [will come] with a gift. [The] rich from among people will seek your {favor}.<note: Literally "face">
passages.45:13: The king's daughter is all glorious within;<note: That is, within her bridal chamber> her garment [is] of gold embroidered cloth.
passages.45:14: She is brought to the king [in] colorful garments. [The] young women behind her, her attendants, [are] being brought to you.
passages.45:15: They are led with joy and gladness. They enter [the] palace of [the] king.
passages.45:16: In place of your<note: The pronouns and verbal forms are masculine in this verse> fathers will be your sons. You will make them princes in all the land.<note: Or "earth">
passages.45:17: I will cause your name to be remembered in all generations; therefore peoples will praise you forever and ever.
passages.46:title: For the [music] director. Of the sons of Korah. According to Alamoth. A song.<note: The Hebrew Bible counts the superscription as the first verse of the psalm; the English verse number is reduced by one>
passages.46:1: God [is] our refuge and strength, a very sufficient help in troubles.
passages.46:2: Therefore we will not fear though [the] earth change, and though the mountains totter into [the] {midst}<note: Literally "heart"> of [the] sea,
passages.46:3: though its waters roar [and] foam, though mountains shake with its surging [water]. Selah
passages.46:4: [There is] a river whose streams gladden the city of God, the holiest of the dwellings of the Most High.
passages.46:5: God [is] in the midst of her; she will not be made to totter. God will help her {at daybreak}.<note: Literally "at the turning of the morning">
passages.46:6: Nations roar, kingdoms shake; he utters his voice, [the] earth melts.
passages.46:7: Yahweh of hosts [is] with us; our [high] stronghold [is] the God of Jacob. Selah
passages.46:8: Come, see the works of Yahweh, who has placed desolations on the earth.
passages.46:9: [He] makes wars cease to the ends of the earth; he breaks [the] bow and cuts off [the] spear. [The] wagons [of war] he burns with fire.
passages.46:10: Be still, and know that I [am] God. I will be exalted among the nations; I will be exalted in the earth.
passages.46:11: Yahweh of Hosts [is] with us; the God of Jacob [is] our [high] stronghold.
passages.47:title: For the [music] director. Of the sons of Korah. A psalm.<note: The Hebrew Bible counts the superscription as the first verse of the psalm; the English verse number is reduced by one>
passages.47:1: All [you] peoples, clap [your] hands.<note: Hebrew "hand"> Shout to God with a voice of rejoicing.
passages.47:2: For Yahweh Most High [is] awesome,<note: Or "to be feared"> a great king over all the earth.
passages.47:3: He subdues peoples under us and nations under our feet.
passages.47:4: He chooses for us our inheritance, the pride of Jacob whom he loves.
passages.47:5: God has gone up with a shout, Yahweh with [the] sound of a trumpet.
passages.47:6: Sing praises [to] God, sing praises. Sing praises to our king, sing praises.
passages.47:7: For God [is] king of all the earth. Sing praises with understanding.<note: Or "sing a maskil">
passages.47:8: God reigns over nations; God sits on his holy throne.
passages.47:9: [The] princes of [the] peoples are gathered together [with] the people of Abraham's God. For [the] shields of [the] earth belong to God. He is very exalted.
passages.48:title: A song. A psalm of the sons of Korah.<note: The Hebrew Bible counts the superscription as the first verse of the psalm; the English verse number is reduced by one>
passages.48:1: Yahweh [is] great and very worthy of praise in the city of our God, in his {holy mountain}.<note: Literally "mountain of holiness">
passages.48:2: Beautiful in elevation, the joy of the whole earth, [is] {Mount Zion},<note: Literally "the mountain of Zion"> {in the far north},<note: Literally "far of north"; the word translated "north" could refer to Mount Zaphon> [the] city of [the] great king.
passages.48:3: God [is] in her citadels; he is known as a [high] stronghold.
passages.48:4: For see, the kings assembled;<note: That is, preparing for battle> they advanced together.
passages.48:5: {They themselves saw}<note: Literally "They, they saw"> [it], so they were astonished. They were terrified; they ran off.
passages.48:6: Trembling seized them there-- pain as of a woman in labor.
passages.48:7: With an east wind you shatter<note: A few Hebrew manuscripts read "like an east wind [that] shatters"> the ships of Tarshish.<note: That is, ships [that can sail to] Tarshish, i.e. well built, able to traverse great distances>
passages.48:8: As we have heard, so we have seen in the city of Yahweh of hosts, in the city of our God. God will establish her forever. Selah
passages.48:9: We have pondered your loyal love, O God, in the midst of your temple.
passages.48:10: As [is] your name, O God, so [is] your praise to [the] ends of [the] earth. Your right hand is full of righteousness.
passages.48:11: Let {Mount Zion}<note: Literally "the mountain of Zion"> rejoice; let the daughters of Judah rejoice because of your judgments.
passages.48:12: Walk about Zion and circle it; count her towers.
passages.48:13: {Consider well}<note: Literally "Set your heart to"> her ramparts. Go through her citadels so that you can tell [the] next generation
passages.48:14: that this [is] God, our God forever and ever. {He himself}<note: Literally "he, he will ..."> will guide us until death.
passages.49:title: For the [music] director. Of the sons of Korah. A psalm.<note: The Hebrew Bible counts the superscription as the first verse of the psalm; the English verse number is reduced by one>
passages.49:1: Hear this, all [you] peoples; give ear, all [you] inhabitants of [the] world,
passages.49:2: both low and high, rich and poor together.
passages.49:3: My mouth will speak wisdom, and the meditation of my heart [will be] understanding.
passages.49:4: I will incline my ear to a proverb; I will {propound}<note: Literally "open"> my riddle on a lyre.
passages.49:5: Why should I fear in {times of calamity},<note: Literally "the days of evil"> [when] iniquity surrounds me at my heels,
passages.49:6: those who trust their wealth and boast about the abundance of their riches?
passages.49:7: Surely a man cannot redeem a brother. He cannot give to God his ransom
passages.49:8: (since<note: Hebrew "and"> the redemption price for their life is costly and it always fails),
passages.49:9: so that he may stay alive forever [and] not see the pit.
passages.49:10: For he sees [that] the wise die, together [with the] fool and brute they perish, and leave their wealth to the next [generation].
passages.49:11: Within them [they think] their houses [are] forever, their dwelling places from generation to generation. They {name}<note: Literally "call"> [their] lands by their [own] names.
passages.49:12: But man cannot continue in [his] pomp. He is like the beasts [that] perish.
passages.49:13: This [is] the journey<note: Hebrew "way"> [of those who] have foolish [confidence], and those after them [who] accept their sayings. Selah
passages.49:14: Like sheep they are destined to Sheol; death will shepherd them. But the upright will rule over them in the morning, and their forms [will be for] Sheol to consume, [far from] his lofty abode.
passages.49:15: Surely God will ransom my life from the {power}<note: Literally "hand"> of Sheol, because he will receive me. Selah
passages.49:16: Do not fear when a man becomes rich, when the wealth<note: Or "honor"> of his house increases,
passages.49:17: because when he dies he will not take [away] any [of it]. His wealth will not follow down after him.
passages.49:18: Though he congratulated his soul while he was living --and [people] will praise you when you do well for yourself--
passages.49:19: it<note: That is, his soul> will go to the generation of his fathers. Never will they see light.
passages.49:20: Humankind in [its] pomp, but does not understand, is like the beasts [that] perish.
passages.50:title: A psalm of Asaph.<note: The Hebrew Bible counts the superscription as the first verse of the psalm>
passages.50:1: The Supreme God, God, Yahweh, has spoken and summoned [the] earth, from [the] rising of [the] sun to its setting.
passages.50:2: From Zion, [the] perfection of beauty, God shines forth.
passages.50:3: Our God comes and he is not silent. Before him fire devours, and around him it is very tempestuous.
passages.50:4: He summons the heavens above and the earth that he might judge his people:
passages.50:5: "Gather to me my loyal ones, [those] who have made a covenant with me by sacrifice."
passages.50:6: And [the] heavens declare his righteousness, because God himself is judge. Selah
passages.50:7: "Hear, O my people, and I will speak, O Israel, and I will testify against you. I am God, your God.
passages.50:8: It is not concerning [a lack of] your sacrifices [that] I rebuke you, and your burnt offerings [are] before me continually.
passages.50:9: I will not take from your house a bull [or] from your stalls a he-goat,
passages.50:10: because every animal of the forest is mine, [the] cattle on a thousand hills.
passages.50:11: I know every bird of [the] mountains, and [every] moving creature in [the] field [is] mine.
passages.50:12: If I were hungry I would not tell you, because [the] world and its fullness [are] mine.
passages.50:13: Do I eat [the] flesh of bulls or drink [the] blood of goats?
passages.50:14: Offer to God a thank offering and pay your vows to [the] Most High.
passages.50:15: And call me in [the] day of trouble; I will deliver you, and you will glorify me."
passages.50:16: But to the wicked God says, "What [right] have you to recite my statutes and {mention my covenant with your mouth},<note: Literally "take my covenant on your mouth">
passages.50:17: while you yourself hate discipline, and cast my words behind you?
passages.50:18: When you see a thief, then you are pleased with him, and your association [is] with adulterers.
passages.50:19: You give your mouth free rein for evil, and you harness your tongue to deceit.
passages.50:20: You sit and speak against your brother; you slander your mother's son.
passages.50:21: These [things] you have done, and I have been silent; You imagined that I was just like you. I will rebuke you and present [an argument] before your eyes.
passages.50:22: Now consider this, you who forget God, lest I tear [you] apart, and there [will be] none to deliver.
passages.50:23: He who sacrifices a thank offering honors me, and he [who] orders [his] way; I will show him the salvation of God."
passages.51:title: For the [music] director. A psalm of David. When Nathan the prophet came to him, after he had gone in to Bathsheba.<note: The Hebrew Bible counts the superscription as the first two verses of the psalm; the English verse number is reduced by two>
passages.51:1: Be gracious to me, O God, according to your loyal love. According to your abundant mercies, blot out my transgressions.
passages.51:2: Wash me thoroughly from my iniquity, and from my sin cleanse me.
passages.51:3: For {I myself know}<note: Literally "I, I know"> my transgressions,<note: Or "rebellions"> and my sin [is] ever before me.
passages.51:4: Against you, only you, I have sinned and have done this evil<note: Hebrew "the evil"> in your eyes, so that you are correct when you speak, you are blameless when you judge.
passages.51:5: Behold, in iniquity I was born, and in sin my mother conceived me.
passages.51:6: Behold, you delight [in] truth in the inward parts, and in [the] hidden [parts] you make me to know wisdom.
passages.51:7: Purify me with hyssop, and I shall be clean. Wash me, and I shall be whiter than snow.
passages.51:8: Make me hear joy and gladness; let [the] bones you have crushed rejoice.
passages.51:9: Hide your face from my sins, and all my iniquities blot out.
passages.51:10: Create a clean heart for me, O God, and renew a steadfast spirit {within me}.<note: Literally "in my inner parts">
passages.51:11: Do not cast me away from your presence, and do not take your Holy Spirit from me.
passages.51:12: Restore to me the joy of your salvation, and with a willing spirit sustain me.
passages.51:13: [Then] I will teach transgressors your ways, and sinners will turn back to you.
passages.51:14: Deliver me from the guilt of bloodshed, O God, the God of my salvation; [then] my tongue will sing aloud [of] your righteousness.
passages.51:15: O Lord, open my lips, and my mouth will proclaim your praise.
passages.51:16: For you do not delight [in] sacrifice or I would give [it]. [With] a burnt offering you are not pleased.
passages.51:17: The sacrifices of God [are] a broken spirit; A broken and contrite heart, O God, you will not despise.
passages.51:18: Do good in your favor toward Zion. Build the walls of Jerusalem.
passages.51:19: Then you will delight [in] righteous sacrifices, burnt offering and whole burnt offering. Then bulls will be offered on your altar.
passages.52:title: For the [music] director. A maskil of David. When Doeg the Edomite came and informed Saul. And he said to him, "David has come to the house of Ahimelech."<note: The Hebrew Bible counts the superscription as the first two verses of the psalm; the English verse number is reduced by two>
passages.52:1: Why do you boast about evil, O mighty man? The loyal love of God [endures] {continually}.<note: Literally "all the day">
passages.52:2: Your tongue plans destruction, like a sharp razor, working deceit.
passages.52:3: You love evil more than good, a lie more than speaking {what is right}.<note: Literally "righteousness"> Selah
passages.52:4: You love all devouring words, O deceitful tongue,
passages.52:5: but God will pull you down forever. He will snatch you and tear you away from [your] tent, and [he] will uproot you from [the] land of [the] living. Selah
passages.52:6: And [the] righteous will see and fear, and will laugh at him, [saying],
passages.52:7: "Look, the man [who] would not make God his refuge, but he trusted in the greatness of his wealth; he took refuge in his destructiveness."
passages.52:8: But I [am] like an olive tree flourishing in the house<note: Or "temple"> of God. I trust the loyal love of God forever and ever.
passages.52:9: I will give thanks to you forever, because [of what] you have done, and I will wait on your name, because [it is] good, in the presence of your faithful ones.
passages.53:title: For the [music] director, according to Mahalath. A maskil of David.<note: The Hebrew Bible counts the superscription as the first verse of the psalm; the English verse number is reduced by one>
passages.53:1: [The] fool says in his heart, "There is no God." They are corrupt and they have done abominable iniquity. There is none who does good.
passages.53:2: God looks down from heaven upon the children of humankind to see whether there is one who has insight, one who seeks God.
passages.53:3: {All of them}<note: Literally "The whole of it," i.e. all of humankind> have turned back. They are altogether corrupt. There is none who does good; there is not even one.
passages.53:4: Do not evildoers know, [they] who eat my people [as though] they were eating bread? They do not call on God.
passages.53:5: There {they are very fearful}<note: Literally "they feared a fear"> [where] no fear had been, because God has scattered the bones of him who encamps [against] you. You have put [them] to shame, because God has rejected them.
passages.53:6: {Oh, that from Zion}<note: Literally "Who will give [that] from Zion"> would come salvation [for] Israel! When God returns the fortunes<note: Or "captivity"> of his people, let Jacob rejoice, let Israel be glad.
passages.54:title: For the [music] director, with stringed instruments. A maskil of David, when the Ziphites went and said to Saul, "Is not David hiding himself among us?"<note: The Hebrew Bible counts the superscription as the first verse of the psalm; the English verse number is reduced by one>
passages.54:1: O God, by your name save me, and by your power vindicate me.
passages.54:2: O God, hear my prayer; heed the words of my mouth.
passages.54:3: For foreigners have risen against me, and ruthless [men] seek my life. They have not set God before them. Selah
passages.54:4: See, God [is] my helper; The Lord [is] with those who sustain my life.<note: Or "The Lord [is] the sustainer of my life.">
passages.54:5: He will repay<note: According to the reading tradition (Qere)> my enemies for their<note: Hebrew "the"> evil; in your faithfulness destroy them.
passages.54:6: I will freely sacrifice to you; I will give thanks [to] your name, O Yahweh, because [it is] good.
passages.54:7: Because he has delivered me from all trouble, and my eye has looked [with satisfaction] on my enemies.
passages.55:title: For the [music] director, with stringed instruments. A maskil of David.<note: The Hebrew Bible counts the superscription as the first verse of the psalm; the English verse number is reduced by one>
passages.55:1: Give ear, O God, [to] my prayer, and do not hide yourself from my plea.
passages.55:2: Attend to me and answer me. I am restless in my lamenting and I groan,
passages.55:3: because of [the] voice [of] an enemy, because of the oppression of the wicked, because they bring down evil on me, and in anger they hold a grudge [against] me.
passages.55:4: My heart trembles within me, and deathly terrors fall on me.
passages.55:5: Fear and trembling come on me, and horror overwhelms me.
passages.55:6: So I say, "{Oh, that}<note: Literally "Who will give that"> I had wings like a dove. I would fly away and be at rest.
passages.55:7: Look, I would flee far away. I would dwell in the wilderness. Selah
passages.55:8: I would hurry to my refuge from [the] raging wind [and] storm."
passages.55:9: Confuse, O Lord; divide their speech, because I see violence and strife in the city.
passages.55:10: Day and night they go around it on its walls, and iniquity and trouble [are] in its midst.
passages.55:11: Destruction [is] within it, and oppression and deceit do not depart from its public square.
passages.55:12: For [it is] not an enemy [that] taunts me, or I could bear [it]. [It is not] one who hates me [that] magnifies himself over me, or I could hide myself from him.
passages.55:13: But [it is] you, a man my equal, my friend and confidant.
passages.55:14: [We] who would take sweet counsel together; in the house<note: Or "temple"> of God we would walk with [the] throng.
passages.55:15: Let death deceive them. May they descend to Sheol alive, because evil [is] in their home [and] {heart}.<note: Literally "inward part">
passages.55:16: As for me, I will call to God, and Yahweh will save me.
passages.55:17: {Morning, noon and night}<note: Literally "evening and morning and noon"> I will lament and groan loudly, and he will hear my voice.
passages.55:18: He safely redeems my life from [the] battle against me,<note: Or "my battle"> because [those standing] against me are among many.
passages.55:19: God will hear and answer them,<note: Or "and humble them"> [he] who [is] enthroned from of old, Selah Because they do not change, and they do not fear God.
passages.55:20: He has put forth his hands against {his friends};<note: Literally "those at peace with him"> he has defiled his covenant.
passages.55:21: The {buttery words}<note: Literally "butter"> of his mouth were smooth, but [there was] battle in his heart. His words were smoother than oil, but they [were] drawn swords.
passages.55:22: Cast your burden on Yahweh, and he will sustain you. He will never allow the righteous to be moved.<note: Or "shaken">
passages.55:23: But you, O God, you will bring them down to [the] pit of corruption. [The] men of bloodshed and deceit will not live half their days, but I will trust you.
passages.56:title: For the [music] director, according to The Silent Dove of Distant [Lands]. Of David. A miktam. When [the] Philistines seized him in Gath.<note: The Hebrew Bible counts the superscription as the first verse of the psalm; the English verse number is reduced by one>
passages.56:1: Be gracious to me, O God, because humankind has trampled me; fighting all the day he oppresses me.
passages.56:2: My enemies<note: Or "lurking foes"> trample all day, because many [are] attacking me proudly.
passages.56:3: {When}<note: Literally "[The] day"> I fear, I trust you.
passages.56:4: God, whose word I praise, God I trust; I do not fear. What can [mere] flesh do to me?
passages.56:5: All day they twist my words; all their thoughts [are] against me for evil.
passages.56:6: They attack,<note: Or "they stir up strife"> they hide, they watch my {steps},<note: Literally "heels"> as they [lie in] wait for my life.
passages.56:7: Because of iniquity will they escape? In anger cast down [the] peoples, O God.
passages.56:8: You have kept count of my wonderings. Put my tears in your bottle; [are they] not in your book?
passages.56:9: Then my enemies will turn back {when}<note: Literally "in the day"> I call.<note: i.e., call on God> This I know because<note: Or "that"> God [is] for me.
passages.56:10: God, [whose] word I praise, Yahweh, [whose] word I praise,
passages.56:11: God I trust; I do not fear. What can [mere] humankind do to me?
passages.56:12: [My] vows [to you], O God, [are binding] upon me. I will pay thank offerings to you,
passages.56:13: because you have delivered my soul from death. [Have you] not [kept] my feet from stumbling, that I may walk before God in the light of the living?
passages.57:title: For the [music] director, [according to] Do Not Destroy. Of David. A miktam. When he fled from Saul into the cave.<note: The Hebrew Bible counts the superscription as the first verse of the psalm; the English verse number is reduced by one>
passages.57:1: Be gracious to me, O God, be gracious to me, because in you my soul takes refuge. In the shadow of your wings I will take refuge until destruction passes by.
passages.57:2: I will call to God Most High, to God who accomplishes [things] concerning me.
passages.57:3: He will send from heaven and save me; he will reproach [the] one who tramples me. Selah God will send his loyal love and his faithfulness.
passages.57:4: My soul [is] among lions. I lie down [among those who] devour-- the children<note: Or "sons"> of humankind whose teeth [are] spears and arrows and whose tongues [are] sharp swords.
passages.57:5: Be exalted above the heavens, O God. [Let] your glory [be] above all the earth.
passages.57:6: They have set a net for my steps; my soul is bowed down. They have dug a pit before me; they have fallen into the midst of it. Selah
passages.57:7: My heart [is] steadfast, O God; My heart [is] steadfast. I will sing and give praise.
passages.57:8: Awake, my glory; Awake, harp and lyre. I will awake [the] dawn.<note: Or "[at] dawn">
passages.57:9: I will give you thanks among the peoples, O Lord; I will give you praise among [the] nations.
passages.57:10: Because your loyal love [is] high to [the] heavens, and your faithfulness to [the] clouds.
passages.57:11: Be exalted above [the] heavens, O God. [Let] your glory [be] above all the earth.
passages.58:title: For the [music] director, [according to] Do not Destroy. Of David. A miktam.<note: The Hebrew Bible counts the superscription as the first verse of the psalm; the English verse number is reduced by one>
passages.58:1: Do you really speak [what is] right [when] silent?<note: A slight emendation of the Hebrew text yields "what is right, O gods," or "O mighty ones"> [Do] you judge fairly the children of humankind?<note: Or "Do you judge fairly, O sons of humankind?">
passages.58:2: No, in [your] heart you plan injustices; in the land<note: Or "on the earth"> you weigh out the violence of your hands.
passages.58:3: The wicked are estranged from [the] womb. They go astray from [the] belly, speaking lies.
passages.58:4: Their venom [is] like snake venom; [They are] like a deaf viper that closes its ear
passages.58:5: so that it does not hear [the] voice of charmers [or the] skilled caster of spells.
passages.58:6: O God, break their teeth in their mouth. Break off [the] fangs of [the] young lions, O Yahweh.
passages.58:7: Let them run [away] like water [that] runs off. [When] he bends [the bow], let his arrows [be] as though they were cut off.<note: Or "as though they were withered [stalks]">
passages.58:8: [Let them be] like a snail [that] melts away [as] it goes; [like the] stillborn of woman [that] do not see [the] sun.
passages.58:9: Before your pots can feel [the heat of] a thornbush, whether green [or] {dry},<note: Literally "burning"> he will sweep it away.<note: The Hebrew of this verse is difficult to interpret>
passages.58:10: [The] righteous will rejoice when he sees [the] vengeance; he will wash his feet in the blood of the wicked.
passages.58:11: And people<note: Hebrew "a person"> will say, "Surely [there is] a {reward}<note: Literally "fruit"> for the righteous. Surely there is a God [who] judges in the land."<note: Or "on the earth">
passages.59:title: For the [music] director, [according to] Do Not Destroy. Of David. A miktam. When Saul dispatched [men] and they watched the house to kill him.<note: The Hebrew Bible counts the superscription as the first verse of the psalm; the English verse number is reduced by one>
passages.59:1: Deliver me from my enemies, O my God. Protect<note: The sense is that of making something inaccessibly high, like a fortress> me from those who rise up against me.
passages.59:2: Deliver me from workers of iniquity, and from men of bloodshed save me.
passages.59:3: For look, they lie in wait for my life.<note: Hebrew "soul"> The mighty attack<note: Or "stir up strife"> against me, not [because of] my transgression or my sin, O Yahweh.
passages.59:4: Without guilt on my part they run and ready themselves. Awake to meet me and see.
passages.59:5: And you, Yahweh, God [of] hosts, [are] the God of Israel. Rouse yourself to punish all the nations. Do not be gracious to any [who] treacherously plot evil. Selah
passages.59:6: They return at evening; they howl like dogs<note: Hebrew "dog"> while they prowl [the] city.
passages.59:7: Look, they pour out [talk] with their mouth. Swords [are] on their lips, for [they say], "Who hears?"
passages.59:8: But you, O Yahweh, will laugh at them; you will mock all [the] nations.
passages.59:9: O my strength,<note: Reading with a few Hebrew manuscripts and the LXX, Targum and v. 17> I will watch for you, because [you], O God, [are] my (high) stronghold.
passages.59:10: My<note: According to the reading tradition (Qere), some Hebrew manuscripts and the LXX> God of loyal love will meet me; God will cause me to look [in triumph] on my enemies.
passages.59:11: Do not kill them, lest my people forget. Make them [to] wander by your power, and bring them down, O Lord, our shield.
passages.59:12: [By] the sin of their mouth [and] the words of their lips, even in their pride, let them be trapped, and for [the] curses<note: Hebrew "curse"> and lies<note: Hebrew "lie"> they proclaim.
passages.59:13: Destroy in anger; destroy so they are no more, so that they may know that God [is] ruling in Jacob to the ends of the earth. Selah
passages.59:14: They return at evening; they howl like dogs<note: Hebrew "dog"> while they prowl [the] city.
passages.59:15: As for them, they wander for food. If they are not satisfied, then they continue all night.<note: Or "then they growl">
passages.59:16: But as for me, I will sing [of] your strength, and I will hail your loyal love in the morning, because you have been my [high] stronghold and a refuge in my {time}<note: Literally "day"> of trouble.
passages.59:17: O my strength, to you I will give praise, because God [is] my [high] stronghold, my God of loyal love.
passages.60:title: For the [music] director, according to Shushan Eduth.<note: Perhaps "The Lily of Testimony"> A miktam of David. To teach. When he fought Mesopotamia and Aram Zobah, and Joab returned and struck Edom in the Valley of Salt, twelve thousand [persons].<note: The Hebrew Bible counts the superscription as the first two verses of the psalm; the English verse number is reduced by two>
passages.60:1: O God, you have rejected us. You have broken us. You have been angry. Restore us!
passages.60:2: You have made [the] land quake. You have split it open. Heal its fissures, because it totters.
passages.60:3: You have shown your people hard [things]; You have given us wine that staggers.
passages.60:4: You have rallied those who fear you round a banner {out of bowshot},<note: Literally "from [the] presence of [the] bow"> Selah
passages.60:5: so that your beloved ones may be rescued. Save by your right hand and answer us.
passages.60:6: God has spoken in his holiness, "I will rejoice; I will divide up Shechem, and portion out the valley of Succoth.
passages.60:7: Gilead [is] mine, and Manasseh [is] mine, and Ephraim [is] the {helmet for}<note: Literally "protection of"> my head; Judah [is] my scepter.<note: Or "commander's rod">
passages.60:8: Moab [is] my washing pot; over Edom, I will cast my sandal. On account of me, O Philistia, raise a shout."
passages.60:9: Who will bring me to [the] fortified city? Who will lead me to Edom?
passages.60:10: Have not you yourself rejected us, O God, and not gone out with our armies, O God?
passages.60:11: Give us help against [the] adversary, for the help of humankind [is] futile.
passages.60:12: Through God we will do {valiantly},<note: Literally "might"> and [it is] he [who] will tread down our enemies.
passages.61:title: For the [music] director, upon stringed instruments.<note: Reading with many Hebrew manuscripts and several translations> Of David.<note: The Hebrew Bible counts the superscription as the first verse of the psalm; the English verse number is reduced by one>
passages.61:1: Hear, O God, my cry; attend to my prayer.
passages.61:2: From the end of the earth<note: Or "the far reaches of the land"> I call to you when my heart grows faint. You will lead me to a rock [that is] higher than I.
passages.61:3: For you have been my refuge, a strong tower from the enemy.
passages.61:4: Let me reside in your tent forever. Let me take refuge under the covering of your wings. Selah
passages.61:5: For you, O God, you have heard my vows. You have given [me] the heritage of those who fear your name.
passages.61:6: You will add days to the days of the king, his years like [those of] {many generations}.<note: Literally "a generation and a generation">
passages.61:7: May he live<note: Or "be enthroned"> forever in the presence of God. Appoint loyal love and faithfulness to preserve him.
passages.61:8: So I will sing the praise of your name forever, that I may fulfill<note: Or "pay"> my vows {daily}.<note: Literally "day, day">
passages.62:title: For the [music] director, on Jeduthun.<note: One of David's musicians (1 Chr 16:41)> A psalm of David.<note: The Hebrew Bible counts the superscription as the first verse of the psalm; the English verse number is reduced by one>
passages.62:1: Only for God my soul [waits in] silence. From him [is] my salvation.
passages.62:2: Only he [is] my rock and my salvation, my [high] stronghold; I shall not be greatly shaken.
passages.62:3: How long will you attack a man? All of you will be shattered<note: Or "All of you shatter [him]"> like a leaning wall, a tottering fence.
passages.62:4: They only<note: This word appears first in the Hebrew verse.> plan to thrust [him] down from his high position; they are pleased [with] deception. With their mouths<note: Hebrew "his mouth"> they bless, but {inwardly}<note: Literally "in the midst of them"> they curse. Selah
passages.62:5: Only for God wait in silence, O my soul, because my hope [is] from him.
passages.62:6: Only he [is] my rock and my salvation, my [high] stronghold; I shall not be shaken.
passages.62:7: On God [rests] my salvation and my glory; God<note: Or "In God"> is my strong rock, my refuge.
passages.62:8: Trust him at all times, O people; pour out before him your heart. God [is] a refuge for us. Selah
passages.62:9: Only a vapor<note: Or "breath"> [are] men of low degree, a deception [are] men of high degree. {Weighed}<note: Literally "To go up"> in a balance, together they [are lighter] than a vapor.
passages.62:10: Do not trust in extortion, and do not put vain [confidence] in robbery. If wealth increases, do not set [your] heart [on it].
passages.62:11: Once God has spoken; twice I have heard this: that strength [belongs] to God.
passages.62:12: And to you [belongs] loyal love, O Lord, because you will render to each according to his work.
passages.63:title: A psalm of David, when [he] was in the wilderness of Judah.<note: The Hebrew Bible counts the superscription as the first verse of the psalm; the English verse number is reduced by one>
passages.63:1: O God, you [are] my God; I will seek you diligently. My soul thirsts for you; my flesh longs for you [as] in a dry and weary land without water.
passages.63:2: Thus I have seen you in the sanctuary, beholding your strength and glory.
passages.63:3: Because your loyal love [is] better than life, my lips will praise you.
passages.63:4: So I will bless you while I live. I will lift up my {hands}<note: Hebrew "palms"> in your name.
passages.63:5: My soul will be satisfied [as with the] best and richest [food], and [with] joyful lips my mouth will praise.
passages.63:6: When I remember you on my bed, I meditate on you in [the] night watches.
passages.63:7: Because you have been my help, therefore<note: Hebrew "and"> in the shadow of your wings I will sing for joy.
passages.63:8: My soul clings to<note: Or "follows hard after"> you; your right hand upholds me.
passages.63:9: But as for them [who] seek my life for ruin, they will go into the depths of the earth.
passages.63:10: They [who] would {deliver him to the sword}<note: Literally "pour him out to the hands of the sword"> will become a portion for jackals.
passages.63:11: However, the king will rejoice in God. Everyone who swears an oath by him will boast, because [the] mouth of [the] liars will be stopped.
passages.64:title: For the [music] director. A psalm of David.<note: The Hebrew Bible counts the superscription as the first verse of the psalm; the English verse number is reduced by one>
passages.64:1: Hear my voice, O God, in my lamenting. Preserve my life from [the] fear of [the] enemy.
passages.64:2: Hide me from [the] secret plots<note: Hebrew "plot"> of evildoers, from [the] unrest of [those who] do iniquity,
passages.64:3: who sharpen their tongue like a sword. They bend [their bow to shoot] their arrows--bitter words,
passages.64:4: to shoot from<note: Hebrew "in"> their<note: Hebrew "the"> hiding places [at the] blameless. Suddenly they shoot [at] him and do not fear.
passages.64:5: They encourage themselves [in the] evil matter. They talk of secretly laying snares. They say, "Who will see them?"
passages.64:6: {They carefully plot}<note: Literally "They search out"> injustices [saying], "We have perfected {the perfect plot}!"<note: Literally "a plotted plot"> Both [the] {inner thought}<note: Literally "inward part"> and heart of [a] man [are] deep.
passages.64:7: But God will shoot them; with an arrow they will suddenly be wounded.
passages.64:8: <note: The Hebrew of this verse is very difficult> And they [who] would cause him<note: That is, the psalmist> to stumble, their [own] tongue [will be] against them. All who gaze on them will shake.<note: Perhaps a shaking of the head; a similar Hebrew form could be translated "will flee">
passages.64:9: And then<note: Hebrew "and"> all men<note: Hebrew "man"> will fear, and will declare the working of God, and will understand his doing.
passages.64:10: [The] righteous will rejoice in Yahweh and take refuge in him, and all [the] upright in heart will boast.
passages.65:title: For the [music] director. A psalm of David. A song.<note: The Hebrew Bible counts the superscription as the first verse of the psalm; the English verse number is reduced by one>
passages.65:1: Praise awaits you, O God, in Zion, and to you [the] vow shall be fulfilled.
passages.65:2: O [you who] hear prayer, to you all flesh will come.
passages.65:3: Iniquities<note: Hebrew "matters of iniquities"> prevail over me. As for our transgressions, you will {forgive}<note: Literally "provide atonement for"> them.
passages.65:4: Blessed [is one whom] you choose and bring near, [that] he may abide in your courts. We will be satisfied with the goodness of your house, your holy temple.
passages.65:5: By awesome deeds in righteousness you will answer us, O God of our salvation, [you who are the] confidence [of] all [the] ends of [the] earth and [of] the far-off seas,
passages.65:6: [who] established the mountains by his strength, [the one who] is girded with might,
passages.65:7: [who] stills [the] roar of [the] seas, the roar of their waves, and [the] commotion of [the] peoples,
passages.65:8: so that<note: Hebrew "and"> [the] inhabitants of [the] farthest reaches are in awe of your signs. You make the dawn and sunset sing for joy.
passages.65:9: You care for<note: Or "visit"> the land<note: Or "earth"> and water it; you greatly enrich it. The stream of God [is] filled with waters. You provide their grain, for so you have established it.
passages.65:10: You drench its furrows, penetrating its ridges. With rains you soften it; its growth you bless.
passages.65:11: You crown the year with your {bounty},<note: Literally "goodness"> and your wagon paths drip with {richness}.<note: Literally "fatness">
passages.65:12: They drop [on the] pastures of [the] wilderness, and the hills gird themselves with joy.
passages.65:13: [The] pasturelands put on flocks, and [the] valleys clothe themselves with grain. They shout in triumph; they even sing.
passages.66:title: For the [music] director. A song. A psalm.<note: The Hebrew Bible counts the superscription as the first verse of the psalm>
passages.66:1: Shout joyfully to God, all the earth.
passages.66:2: Sing the glory of his name. {Set forth his glorious praise}.<note: Literally "set for glory--his praise">
passages.66:3: Say to God, "How awesome are your works! Because of the greatness of your strength, your enemies will cringe before you.
passages.66:4: All the earth will bow in worship to you, and sing [praise] to you. They will sing [the praise of] your name." Selah
passages.66:5: Come and {consider}<note: Literally "see"> the works of God; [he is] awesome [in his] dealings<note: Hebrew "dealing"> with the children of humankind.
passages.66:6: He turned [the] sea into dry ground; they passed through the river on foot. There we rejoiced in him.
passages.66:7: [He] rules by his might forever; his eyes keep watch on the nations. Do not let the rebellious exalt themselves.<note: According to the reading tradition (Qere)> Selah
passages.66:8: Bless our God, O peoples, and cause the sound of his praise to be heard,
passages.66:9: the one who has kept our soul among the living, and has not allowed our foot to slip.
passages.66:10: For you have tested us, O God; you have tried us as silver is tried.
passages.66:11: You brought us into the net; you placed a {heavy burden}<note: Literally "oppression"> on our backs.
passages.66:12: You let men<note: Hebrew "man"> ride over our heads. We went through fire and through water, but you have brought us out to the place of abundance.<note: A slightly different Hebrew word yields "a broad place">
passages.66:13: I will come into your house<note: Or "temple"> with burnt offerings. I will pay to you my vows
passages.66:14: that my lips uttered, and my mouth spoke in my distress.
passages.66:15: Burnt offerings of fat animals I will offer to you, with [the] smoke of rams. I will do<note: That is, "offer"> cattle with rams. Selah
passages.66:16: Come [and] hear, all you God-fearers, and I will tell what he has done for me.<note: Hebrew "my soul">
passages.66:17: I called to him with my mouth, and he was extolled with my tongue.<note: A slightly different Hebrew word yields "his exaltation was under my tongue">
passages.66:18: If I had considered evil in my heart, the Lord would not have listened.
passages.66:19: However, God has listened; he has attended to the sound of my prayer.
passages.66:20: Blessed be God, who has not turned aside my prayer, or his loyal love from me.
passages.67:title: For the [music] director, with stringed instruments. A psalm. A song.<note: The Hebrew Bible counts the superscription as the first verse of the psalm; the English verse number is reduced by one>
passages.67:1: May God be gracious to us and bless us. May he cause his face to shine toward us, Selah
passages.67:2: that your way may be known on the earth, your salvation among all nations.
passages.67:3: Let the peoples praise you, O God; let all of the peoples praise you.
passages.67:4: Let the nations be glad and sing for joy, because you judge [the] peoples with equity and guide the nations on the earth. Selah
passages.67:5: Let [the] peoples praise you, O God; let all [the] peoples praise you.
passages.67:6: [The] earth has yielded its produce. God, our God, will bless us.
passages.67:7: God will bless us, and all [the] ends of [the] earth will fear him.
passages.68:title: For the [music] director. Of David. A psalm. A song.<note: The Hebrew Bible counts the superscription as the first verse of the psalm; the English verse number is reduced by one>
passages.68:1: God will arise; his enemies will be scattered, and those who hate him will flee from before him.
passages.68:2: As smoke is driven off, you will drive [them] off. As wax melts before fire, [the] wicked will perish before God.
passages.68:3: But [the] righteous will be glad; they will exalt before God, and will rejoice with joy.
passages.68:4: Sing to God, sing praises to his name. Lift up [a song] to [the] rider on the clouds--his name is Yah--<note: A shortened form of "Yahweh"> and rejoice before him.
passages.68:5: A father to orphans and a judge for widows [is] God in his holy habitation.
passages.68:6: God settles the lonely in a home; he brings prisoners out into prosperity. But the rebellious abide in a barren land.
passages.68:7: O God, when you went out before your people, when you marched through [the] desert, Selah
passages.68:8: [the] earth shook; [the] heavens also dripped [rain] at the presence of God who [was] at Sinai, at the presence of God, the God of Israel.
passages.68:9: You caused abundant rain to fall, O God. When your inheritance was weary you revived it.
passages.68:10: Your community dwelled in it. You provided in your goodness for the poor, O God.
passages.68:11: The Lord gives [the] word. Great is the company of women who announce:
passages.68:12: "[The] kings of armies flee, they flee, and she [who] remains at home divides [the] spoil.
passages.68:13: Though you [men] lie down between the sheepfolds, [you will be like the] wings of a dove covered in silver and its pinions in yellow gold."
passages.68:14: When Shaddai scattered kings on it, on Zalmon it snowed.<note: Or "you caused it to snow on">
passages.68:15: A mountain of God<note: Or "A mighty mountain"> [is] the mountain of Bashan; a mountain of [many] peaks [is] the mountain of Bashan.
passages.68:16: Why do you look with hostility, O many-peaked mountains? This<note: Hebrew "The"> mountain God desires for his dwelling. Yes, Yahweh will abide [in it] forever.
passages.68:17: The chariots of God [are] twice ten thousand, [with] thousands doubled. The Lord [is] among them [at] Sinai, distinctive [in victory].<note: Or "[as at] Sinai, in the sanctuary">
passages.68:18: You have ascended on high; you have led away captives. You have received gifts [from] among humankind, and even [from the] rebellious, so that Yah<note: A shortened form of "Yahweh"> God may dwell [there].
passages.68:19: Blessed be the Lord. Daily he loads us [with benefits],<note: Or "daily carries our burden"> the God [of] our salvation.<note: Or "victory"> Selah
passages.68:20: Our God [is] a God of deliverances, and to [the] Yahweh the Lord belong escapes from death.
passages.68:21: But God will shatter the head of his enemies, the hairy scalp [of the one who] {continues on}<note: Literally "is walking about"> in his guilt.
passages.68:22: The Lord said, "I will bring [them] back from Bashan; I will bring [them] back from [the] depths of [the] sea,
passages.68:23: so that your foot may shatter [them] bloody [for] the tongues of your dogs [to have] their share from [the] enemies."
passages.68:24: They have seen your processions, O God, the processions of my God, my king, distinctive [in victory].<note: Or "into the sanctuary">
passages.68:25: Singers went up front, those playing stringed instruments last, between [them] young women [playing] tambourines.
passages.68:26: Bless God in [the] assemblies, Yahweh from the fountain of Israel.
passages.68:27: There [is] little Benjamin ruling them, [with] the princes of Judah [in] their throng, the princes of Zebulun [and] the princes of Naphtali.
passages.68:28: Your God has commanded your strength. Show yourself strong, O God, [by] what you perform<note: Or "you who have worked"> for us.
passages.68:29: Because your temple [is] above Jerusalem, kings will bring tribute to you.
passages.68:30: Rebuke [the] beasts in<note: Hebrew "of"> [the] reeds, [the] herd of bulls with [the] calves of [the] peoples, trampling the pieces of silver.<note: Or "[until each] humbles himself [by offering] pieces of silver"> Scatter [the] nations [who] delight in battles.
passages.68:31: Ambassadors<note: Reading with the LXX; meaning uncertain> will come from Egypt; Cush will quickly stretch out her hands to God.
passages.68:32: O kingdoms of the earth, sing to God; sing praise to [the] Lord, Selah
passages.68:33: to the one who rides in the highest heavens of old. See, he gives forth his voice, a mighty voice.
passages.68:34: Ascribe strength to God. His majesty [is] over Israel, and his strength [is] in the clouds.
passages.68:35: Awesome [are you], O God, from your sanctuary.<note: Hebrew "sanctuaries"> The God of Israel, [it is] he who gives strength and might to the people. Blessed be God.
passages.69:title: For the [music] director, according to [The] Lilies. Of David.<note: The Hebrew Bible counts the superscription as the first verse of the psalm; the English verse number is reduced by one>
passages.69:1: Save me, O God, because waters have come up to [my] neck.<note: Hebrew "soul" or "life">
passages.69:2: I sink in [the] mud of the deep, and there is no foothold. I have come to watery depths, and [the] torrent floods over me.
passages.69:3: I am weary with my calling [out]; my throat is parched. My eyes are exhausted [in my] waiting for my God.
passages.69:4: More numerous than the hairs of my head are [those] hating me without a cause. [Those who are] destroying me--my enemies wrongfully<note: Or, "those who oppose me [with] falsehood">-- are mighty. What I did not steal, I then must restore.
passages.69:5: O God, {you yourself know}<note: Literally "you, you know"> my foolishness, and my guilty deeds are not hidden from you.
passages.69:6: Let those who wait for you not be put to shame because of me, O Lord Yahweh [of] hosts. Let those who seek you not be disgraced because of me, O God of Israel.
passages.69:7: Because on account of you I have borne reproach; disgrace has covered my face.
passages.69:8: I have become a stranger to my brothers and a foreigner to my mother's sons,
passages.69:9: because the zeal for your house<note: Or "temple"> has consumed me, and the reproaches of those reproaching you have fallen on me.
passages.69:10: When I wept in the fasting of my soul, it became reproaches for me.
passages.69:11: When I made sackcloth my clothing, I became for them a byword.
passages.69:12: Those sitting at [the] gate talk about me [as] also<note: Hebrew "and"> [the] songs of [the] drunkards.
passages.69:13: But as for me, my prayer [is] to you, O Yahweh, for a favorable time, O God, according to the abundance of your loyal love. Answer me with the faithfulness of your salvation.
passages.69:14: Deliver me from [the] mud and do not let me sink. Let me be delivered from [those who] hate me and from [the] watery depths.
passages.69:15: Do not let the torrent of waters flood over me, or [the] deep swallow me, or the pit close its mouth over me.
passages.69:16: Answer me, O Yahweh, because your loyal love [is] good; according to your abundant mercies, turn to me,
passages.69:17: and do not hide your face from your servant. Because I am in trouble, answer me quickly.
passages.69:18: Draw near to my soul; redeem it. Because of my enemies, ransom me.
passages.69:19: You know my reproach, my shame and my disgrace. {Fully known}<note: Literally "[right] in front of"> to you are all my adversaries.
passages.69:20: Reproach has broken my heart and I am sick. And I hoped for sympathy, but there was none, and for comforters, but I found none.
passages.69:21: They also gave me gall for food,<note: Or "they put poison in my food"> and for my thirst they gave me vinegar to drink.
passages.69:22: Let their table before them be a trap, and their [times of] peace a snare.
passages.69:23: Let their eyes be dark so they cannot see, and make their loins continually tremble.
passages.69:24: Pour out your indignation on them, and let your burning anger overtake them.
passages.69:25: Let their camp be desolate. Let none dwell in their tents,
passages.69:26: because they persecute [those] whom you, yourself, have struck, and they tell of the pain of [those] you have wounded.
passages.69:27: {Add guilt on top of their guilt},<note: Literally "Give guilt on their guilt"> and do not let them {be acquitted}.<note: Literally "come into your righteousness">
passages.69:28: Let them be blotted out of [the] book of [the] living, and let them not be recorded with [the] righteous.
passages.69:29: But as for me, [though] I [am] afflicted and pained, your salvation will protect<note: The sense is that of making something inaccessibly high, like a fortress> me, O God.
passages.69:30: I will praise the name of God in song, and magnify him with thanksgiving.
passages.69:31: For Yahweh it will be better than an ox [or] bull, horned [and] hoofed.<note: That is, mature and ritually clean>
passages.69:32: [The] afflicted will see [and] rejoice. O God seekers, let your heart revive,<note: Or "live">
passages.69:33: because Yahweh hears [the] needy and does not despise his [own who are] prisoners.
passages.69:34: Let heavens and earth praise him, [the] seas and all that moves in them,
passages.69:35: because God will save Zion and build the cities of Judah, that they may dwell there and possess it.
passages.69:36: And the offspring of his servants will inherit it, and [those who] love his name will abide in it.
passages.70:title: For the [music] director. Of David. To bring to remembrance.<note: The Hebrew Bible counts the superscription as the first verse of the psalm; the English verse number is reduced by one>
passages.70:1: O God, [make haste] to deliver me. O Yahweh, make haste to help me.
passages.70:2: Let them be ashamed and abashed who seek my life. Let them be repulsed and humiliated [who] desire my harm.
passages.70:3: let them turn back because of their shame, those who say, "Aha! Aha!"
passages.70:4: Let them rejoice and be glad in you, all those who seek you. Let them say continually, "God is great!" [those] who love your salvation.
passages.70:5: But I [am] poor and needy; O God hasten to me. You [are] my help and my deliverer. O Yahweh, do not delay.
passages.71:1: In you, O Yahweh, I have taken refuge; let me never be put to shame.
passages.71:2: In your righteousness deliver me and rescue me; incline your ear to me and save me.
passages.71:3: Be for me a rock of refuge to resort to always; you have ordained<note: Or "commanded"> to save me, because you [are] my rock and my fortress.
passages.71:4: My God, rescue me from [the] hand of [the] wicked, from [the] {grasp}<note: Literally "palm"> of [the] evildoer and [the] oppressor,
passages.71:5: because you [are] my hope, O Lord Yahweh, my confidence from my youth.
passages.71:6: Upon you I have leaned {from birth}.<note: Literally "from the belly"> [It was] you who {took}<note: Literally "cut," that is, the umbilical cord> me from the womb of my mother. My praise [is] of you continually.
passages.71:7: I have become a wonder to many, but you [are] my strong refuge.
passages.71:8: My mouth is filled with your praise, with your glory all the day.
passages.71:9: Do not cast me away in the time of old age; when my strength fails do not abandon me.
passages.71:10: For my enemies talk concerning me, and those who watch for my life conspire together,
passages.71:11: saying, "His God has abandoned him. Pursue and seize him, because there is no deliverer."
passages.71:12: O God, do not be far from me. My God, hurry to help me.
passages.71:13: Let them be ashamed; let them perish who are {my adversaries}.<note: Literally "adversaries of my soul"> Let [them] wrap themselves with scorn and disgrace who seek my harm.
passages.71:14: But as for me, I will hope continually and increase your praise.
passages.71:15: My mouth will tell of your righteousness, your salvation {all day long},<note: Literally "all the day"> though I do not know [the full] sum [of them].
passages.71:16: I will come in [to tell] the mighty deeds of Lord Yahweh. I will {make known}<note: Literally "bring to remembrance"> your righteousness, yours only.
passages.71:17: O God, you have taught me from my youth, and up to now I have proclaimed your wonderful deeds.
passages.71:18: And even when [I am] old and gray, O God, do not abandon me until I proclaim your {strength}<note: Literally "arm"> to [this] generation, your power to every [one that] comes [after].
passages.71:19: And your righteousness, O God, [is] to [the] height [of heaven]. You who have done great things, O God, who [is] like you?
passages.71:20: You who have caused me<note: According to the reading tradition (Qere)> to see many troubles and evils, you will again revive me.<note: According to the reading tradition (Qere)> And from the depths of the earth you will again bring me up.
passages.71:21: You will increase my greatness, and you will comfort me all around.<note: A slightly different vocalization yields, "... comfort me again"; compare the LXX.>
passages.71:22: On my part, I will praise you with a stringed instrument, [and] your faithfulness, O my God. I will sing praises to you with a lyre, O Holy One of Israel.
passages.71:23: My lips will sing for joy when I sing praises to you, and my soul, which you have redeemed.
passages.71:24: My tongue also will speak of your righteousness all the day, because they have been put to shame, because they have been humiliated who seek my harm.
passages.72:title: Of Solomon.<note: The Hebrew Bible counts the superscription as the first verse of the psalm>
passages.72:1: O God, give your judgments to [the] king, and your righteousness to [the] king's son.
passages.72:2: May he judge your people with righteousness, and your poor with justice.
passages.72:3: Let [the] mountains yield prosperity<note: Or "peace"> for the people, and [the] hills in righteousness.
passages.72:4: May he provide justice [for the] poor of [the] people, save [the] children of [the] needy, and crush [the] oppressor.
passages.72:5: May he live long<note: This presupposes the reading, suggested by the LXX, that might indicate that two of the Hebrew root letters have been inverted. The Hebrew reads "They will/Let them fear"> {while the sun endures}<note: Literally "with [the] sun"> {as long as the moon}<note: Literally "in the presence of the moon"> {for all generations}.<note: Literally "generation of generations">
passages.72:6: May he descend like rain on mown grass, like showers watering [the] earth.
passages.72:7: May [what is] right blossom in his days and an abundance of peace, until [the] moon is no more.
passages.72:8: And may he rule from sea up to sea, and from [the] River<note: That is, the Euphrates> to [the] edges of [the] land.
passages.72:9: Let [the] desert dwellers bow down before him, and his enemies lick the dust.
passages.72:10: Let the kings of Tarshish and [the] islands bring tribute. Let the kings of Sheba and Seba present gifts,
passages.72:11: and let all kings bow down to him. Let all nations serve him.
passages.72:12: Indeed he will deliver [the] needy [who is] crying for help, and [the] afflicted [who] has no helper.
passages.72:13: He will take pity on [the] helpless and needy, and [the] lives of [the] needy he will save.
passages.72:14: From oppression and from violence he will redeem their lives, and their blood will be precious in his eyes.
passages.72:15: So may he live, and may gold from Sheba be given to him, and may prayers be offered for him continually. May blessings be invoked for him {all day long}.<note: Literally "all the day">
passages.72:16: May there be an abundance of grain in the land [even] on [the] top of [the] mountains. May his crop<note: Or "May his descendants"> sway like the [trees of] Lebanon, and may [those] from [the] city blossom like the grass of the earth.
passages.72:17: May his name endure forever. May his name increase {as long as the sun shines},<note: Literally "[in the] presence of the sun"> and let them be blessed in him. Let all nations call him blessed.
passages.72:18: Blessed be Yahweh God, the God of Israel, [who] alone does wonderful things.
passages.72:19: And blessed be his glorious name forever, and may the whole earth be filled with his glory. Amen and Amen.
passages.72:20: The prayers of David, the son of Jesse, are completed.
passages.73:title: A song of Asaph.<note: The Hebrew Bible counts the superscription as the first verse of the psalm>
passages.73:1: Surely God is good to Israel, to those pure of heart.
passages.73:2: But as for me, my feet had almost stumbled. My steps had nearly slipped,
passages.73:3: because I envied the boastful [when] I saw [the] well-being<note: Or "peace" or "prosperity"> of [the] wicked.
passages.73:4: For there are no pains up to their death, and their bodies [are] {healthy}.<note: Literally "fat">
passages.73:5: They do not have {ordinary trouble},<note: Literally "the trouble of man"> and they are not plagued as [other] people.<note: Hebrew "humankind">
passages.73:6: Therefore pride is their necklace; an outfit of violence covers them.
passages.73:7: Their eye bulges from fat.<note: A slightly different Hebrew reading might be reflected in the LXX's "their iniquity comes out of fatness"> Imaginings overflow [their] heart.
passages.73:8: They mock and speak maliciously of oppression; they speak [as though] from on high.
passages.73:9: They set their mouth against the heavens, and their tongue roams the earth.
passages.73:10: Therefore his people turn there,<note: That is, toward the wicked> and abundant waters are slurped up by them.
passages.73:11: And they say, "How does God know?" and, "Does the Most High have knowledge?"
passages.73:12: See, these [are the] wicked, and they increase wealth, ever carefree.
passages.73:13: Surely in vain I have kept my heart pure, and washed my hands in innocence.
passages.73:14: And I have been plagued all day and rebuked {every morning}.<note: Literally "to the mornings">
passages.73:15: If I had said, "I will speak thus," behold, I would have acted treacherously against your children's generation.
passages.73:16: When I thought about [how] to understand this, it [was] troubling in my eyes
passages.73:17: until I went into the sanctuary of God. [Then] I understood their fate.
passages.73:18: Surely you set them on slippery places. You cause them to fall onto ruin.<note: Or "fall for deceptions">
passages.73:19: How they become a desolation in a moment! They come to a complete end by terrors.
passages.73:20: Like a dream upon awakening, when [you] wake up, O Lord, you will despise their fleeting form.<note: Or "image">
passages.73:21: When my heart was embittered and I felt stabbed in my kidneys,
passages.73:22: then I was brutish and ignorant. With you I was [like] the beasts.
passages.73:23: But I [am] continually with you; you have hold of my right hand.
passages.73:24: You will guide me with your advice, and afterward you will take me [into] honor.<note: Or "[to] glory">
passages.73:25: Whom do I have in the heavens [except you]? And with you I have no [other] desire on earth.
passages.73:26: My flesh and heart failed, [but] God [is] the {strength}<note: Literally "rock"> of my heart and my reward forever.
passages.73:27: For indeed, [those] distancing themselves from you will be ruined. You destroy each who abandons you for harlotry.
passages.73:28: But as for me, the approach to God [is] for my good. I have set the Lord Yahweh [as] my refuge, in order to tell all your works.
passages.74:title: A maskil of Asaph.<note: The Hebrew Bible counts the superscription as the first verse of the psalm>
passages.74:1: Why, O God, have you rejected [us] forever? [Why] does your anger smoke against the sheep of your pasture?
passages.74:2: Remember your congregation [that] you bought long ago, [when] you redeemed the tribe of your inheritance. [Remember] {Mount Zion}<note: Literally "the mountain of Zion"> where you have dwelt.
passages.74:3: Lift your steps to the perpetual ruins, [to] all [that the] enemy has ruined in the sanctuary.
passages.74:4: Your enemies have roared in the midst of your meeting place; they have set up their signs [for] signs.
passages.74:5: They are<note: Hebrew "He is"> known [to be] like [those who] {wield}<note: Literally "lift up"> axes in a thicket of trees.
passages.74:6: And now<note: According to the reading tradition (Qere)> its<note: That is, the temple's> carved works altogether they have smashed with axe and hammer.
passages.74:7: They have set fire to your sanctuary. They have defiled to the ground, the dwelling place for your name.
passages.74:8: They have said in their heart, "We will completely<note: Hebrew "altogether"> oppress them." They burned all the meeting places of God in the land.
passages.74:9: We do not see our signs, and there is no longer a prophet. No one with us knows how long.
passages.74:10: How long, O God, will [the] adversary taunt? Will [the] enemy treat your name with contempt forever?
passages.74:11: Why do you draw back your hand, even your right hand? [Take it] from your bosom;<note: According to the reading tradition (Qere)> destroy [them]!
passages.74:12: But God [has been] my king from long ago, working salvation in the midst of the earth.
passages.74:13: You split open [the] sea by your strength; You broke [the] heads of [the] sea monsters in the waters.
passages.74:14: You crushed the heads of Leviathan; you gave him [as] food to [the] desert dwelling creatures.
passages.74:15: You split open spring and wadi.<note: A seasonal stream that is often dry> You dried up ever-flowing rivers.
passages.74:16: Yours [is the] day, yours [is the] night also. You established light and [the] sun.
passages.74:17: You defined<note: Or "set"> all [the] boundaries of [the] earth; Summer and winter--you formed them.
passages.74:18: O Yahweh, remember this: [the] enemy taunts, and foolish people treat your name with contempt.
passages.74:19: Do not give to beasts the life of your dove; do not ever forget the life of your afflicted ones.
passages.74:20: Have regard for the covenant, because [the] dark places of [the] land are full of [the] haunts of violence.
passages.74:21: Do not let [the] oppressed turn back humiliated; let [the] poor and needy praise your name.
passages.74:22: Rise up, O God, plead your cause; remember the reproaching of you by [the] foolish {all day long}.<note: Literally "all the day">
passages.74:23: Do not forget the sound of your adversaries, the roar of those rising up against you ascending continually.
passages.75:title: For the [music] director, [according to] Do Not Destroy. A psalm of Asaph. A song.<note: The Hebrew Bible counts the superscription as the first verse of the psalm; the English verse number is reduced by one>
passages.75:1: We give thanks to you, O God; we give thanks, and your name is near. Your wonderful deeds are told.<note: Hebrew "They tell your wonderful deeds">
passages.75:2: "I will indeed set an appointed time; I will judge fairly.<note: Hebrew "I, I will judge" might be emphatic>
passages.75:3: [The] earth and all its inhabitants [are] shaking;<note: Or "melting away"> I steady<note: Hebrew "I, I steady" might be emphatic> its columns. Selah
passages.75:4: I say to the boastful, 'Do not boast!' and to the wicked, 'Do not lift up [your] horn!
passages.75:5: Do not lift up high your<note: Plural> horn. Do [not] speak with {arrogant pride}.'"<note: Hebrew "an unrestrained neck">
passages.75:6: For [it is] not from [the] east or [the] west and not from [the] south<note: Hebrew "wilderness"> [that] lifting up [comes],
passages.75:7: rather God [is the] judge; one he brings low, and another he lifts up.
passages.75:8: For [there is] a cup in the hand of Yahweh with<note: Hebrew "and"> wine [that] foams, fully mixed, and he pours out from this. Surely all [the] wicked of [the] land {will quaff it down [to] its dregs}. <note: Literally "they will drain, they will drink its dregs">
passages.75:9: But as for me, I will proclaim forever; I will sing praise to the God of Jacob.
passages.75:10: "And all [the] horns of [the] wicked I will cut off. [The] horns of [the] righteous will be lifted up."
passages.76:title: For the [music] director, with stringed instruments. A psalm of Asaph. A song.<note: The Hebrew Bible counts the superscription as the first verse of the psalm; the English verse number is reduced by one>
passages.76:1: God [is] known in Judah. His name [is] great in Israel.
passages.76:2: His den<note: Or "shelter"; but the image of the lion appears in view> has been in Salem, his lair<note: Or "refuge"> in Zion.
passages.76:3: There he broke [the] flames of [the] bow, [the] shield and sword and battle. Selah
passages.76:4: Radiant<note: A possible change in the Hebrew text yields, "You are feared, majestic ..." a form found in vv. 8(7), 13(12). This is possibly reflected in the reading of Theodotian> you [are], majestic, from<note: Or "more than"> [the] mountains of prey.
passages.76:5: [The] stouthearted are plundered; they sleep their sleep, and all [the] able men cannot {use}<note: Literally "find"> their hands.
passages.76:6: At your rebuke, O God of Jacob, both rider<note: Hebrew "chariot," that is, charioteer> and horse slumber.
passages.76:7: {You, indeed, are to be feared},<note: Literally "You, feared you [are]"> and who can stand before you when you [are] angry? <note: A slight change in the vocalization of the MT yields, "from the strength of your anger">
passages.76:8: From heaven you proclaimed judgment. [The] earth feared and was still
passages.76:9: when God rose for justice, to save all [the] afflicted of [the] land. Selah
passages.76:10: For the anger of humankind will praise you. You will put on [the] remnant of anger.<note: Hebrew "angers">
passages.76:11: Make vows and fulfill them to Yahweh, your God; let all surrounding him bring tribute to the [one to be] feared.<note: Hebrew "to the fear">
passages.76:12: He cuts off [the] spirit of leaders. [He is to be] feared by [the] kings of [the] earth.
passages.77:title: For the [music] director, on Jeduthun.<note: One of David's musicians (1 Chr 16:41)> Of Asaph. A psalm.<note: The Hebrew Bible counts the superscription as the first verse of the psalm; the English verse number is reduced by one>
passages.77:1: I cry out with my voice to God; with my voice to God, that he may hear me.
