passages.77:2: In the day I [have] trouble, I seek<note: Or "make supplication to"> the Lord. At night my hand stretches out {continually};<note: Literally "it does not grow weary"> my soul refuses to be comforted.
passages.77:3: I remember God and I groan loudly; I meditate and my spirit grows faint.
passages.77:4: You hold [open] my eyelids. I am troubled and cannot speak.
passages.77:5: I think about [the] days from long ago, [the] years of ancient times.
passages.77:6: I remember my song in the night. With my heart I meditate, and my spirit searches [to understand].
passages.77:7: Will the Lord reject [us] forever, and will he never be pleased [with us] again?
passages.77:8: Has his loyal love ceased forever? Is [his] promise<note: Hebrew "word"> ended throughout generations?
passages.77:9: Has God forgotten to have compassion? Or has he closed off his mercies in anger? Selah
passages.77:10: So I said, "This pierces me--<note: Or "this is my sickness"> the right [hand] of the Most High [has] changed."
passages.77:11: I will remember the deeds of Yah.<note: A shortened form of "Yahweh"> Surely I will remember your wonders<note: Hebrew "wonder"> from long ago.
passages.77:12: I will also muse on all your work, and meditate on your deeds.
passages.77:13: O God, your way [is] distinctive.<note: Or "holy" or "set apart"> Who [is] a great god like [our] God?
passages.77:14: You [are] the God who works wonders;<note: Hebrew "wonder"> you have made known your might among the peoples.
passages.77:15: With [your] arm you redeemed your people, the children of Jacob and Joseph. Selah
passages.77:16: Waters saw you, O God; waters saw you [and] they trembled. Surely [the] deeps shook.
passages.77:17: [The] clouds poured out water. [The] skies {thundered}.<note: Literally "gave voice"> Your arrows also {flew about}.<note: Literally "walked back and forth">
passages.77:18: The sound of your thunder [was] in the whirlwind;<note: Or "in [your chariot] wheel"> lightnings lit [the] world; the earth shook and quaked.
passages.77:19: Your way [was] through the sea, and your path<note: According to the reading tradition (Qere)> through many waters. Yet your footprints were not discerned.<note: Hebrew "were not known">
passages.77:20: You led your people like a flock by the hand of Moses and Aaron.
passages.78:title: A maskil of Asaph.<note: The Hebrew Bible counts the superscription as the first verse of the psalm>
passages.78:1: Listen, O my people, to my teaching. Incline your ears to the words of my mouth.
passages.78:2: I will offer<note: Hebrew "open"> a parable [with] my mouth. I will pour out riddles from long ago,
passages.78:3: that we have heard and known, and our ancestors<note: Or "fathers"> have told us.
passages.78:4: We will not hide [them] from their children,<note: Or "descendants"> telling the next generation the praises of Yahweh, and his power and his wonders that he has done.
passages.78:5: For he established a testimony in Jacob, and appointed a law<note: Hebrew torah> in Israel, which he commanded our ancestors<note: Or "fathers"> to teach to their children,
passages.78:6: so that [the] next generation might know-- children [yet to] be born-- [that] they might rise up and tell their children,
passages.78:7: that they might set their confidence in God, and not forget the deeds of God, but keep his commandments,
passages.78:8: and not be like their ancestors,<note: Or "fathers"> a stubborn and rebellious generation, a generation [that] did not make ready its heart, whose spirit was not faithful [to] God.
passages.78:9: The sons of Ephraim, {armed with archers},<note: Literally "armed with shooters of the bow"> turned back on [the] day of battle.
passages.78:10: They did not keep the covenant of God and refused to go in his law.<note: Hebrew torah>
passages.78:11: They also forgot his deeds, and his wonders that he had shown them.
passages.78:12: In front of their ancestors<note: Or "fathers"> he did a wonder, in the land of Egypt, [in] the region of Zoan.
passages.78:13: He split the sea and caused them to go over, and he caused waters to stand like a heap.
passages.78:14: And he led them with the cloud by day, and all night with a fiery light.
passages.78:15: He caused rocks to split in the wilderness and provided drink abundantly as [from the] depths.
passages.78:16: And he brought streams out of [the] rock and caused water to flow down like rivers.
passages.78:17: But they sinned still further against him by rebelling [against the] Most High in the desert.
passages.78:18: And they tested God in their heart [by] asking food {for their craving}.<note: Literally "for their soul">
passages.78:19: And they spoke against God. They said, "Is God able to prepare a table in the wilderness?
passages.78:20: Yes, he struck [the] rock and water flowed and streams gushed out, [but] can he also give food or provide meat for his people?"
passages.78:21: Therefore Yahweh heard and he was very angry, and a fire was kindled against Jacob, and [his] anger also rose up against Israel,
passages.78:22: because they did not believe God, and they did not trust his salvation.
passages.78:23: Nevertheless, he commanded [the] skies above and opened [the] doors of heaven,
passages.78:24: and rained down on them manna to eat and gave them the grain of heaven.
passages.78:25: Humankind ate [the] bread of {angels}.<note: Literally "mighty ones"> He sent them food [enough] to be satisfied.
passages.78:26: He caused [the] east wind to blow in the heavens and drove along [the] south wind by his strength.
passages.78:27: Then he rained meat on them like dust, even winged birds<note: Hebrew "bird"> like [the] sand of [the] seas.
passages.78:28: He caused [them] to fall in the midst of his camp, all around his dwellings.
passages.78:29: So they ate and were well filled, and he brought about [what] they craved.
passages.78:30: They had not yet turned aside from their craving, [while] their food [was] still in their mouth,
passages.78:31: the anger of God rose against them, and he killed some of the stoutest of them, even the young men of Israel he caused to bow down [in death].
passages.78:32: In spite of all this they sinned further and did not believe his wonders.
passages.78:33: And he consumed their days with futility <note: Or "he ended their days like a breath"> their years with terror.<note: Or "and their years suddenly">
passages.78:34: When he killed [some of] them, then they sought him, and repented and earnestly sought God.
passages.78:35: And they remembered that God [was] their rock, and God Most High their redeemer.
passages.78:36: But they enticed him with their mouth and lied to him with their tongue.
passages.78:37: For their heart was not steadfast with him, nor were they faithful to his covenant.
passages.78:38: But he [was] compassionate; he pardoned<note: Or "covered," or "atoned for"> [their] guilt and did not destroy [them]. And many [times] he turned back his anger and did not stir up all his wrath,
passages.78:39: for he remembered that they [were] flesh, a passing wind that does not return.
passages.78:40: How often they rebelled against him in the wilderness and vexed him in [the] wasteland!
passages.78:41: So they again tested God and distressed<note: Or perhaps, "pressed to the limit"> the Holy One of Israel.
passages.78:42: And they did not remember his {power}<note: Literally "hand"> {when}<note: Literally "the day that"> he redeemed them from the enemy,
passages.78:43: how he performed<note: Hebrew "set"> his signs in Egypt and his wonders in the region of Zoan,
passages.78:44: when he turned their rivers<note: Normally the word for the Nile, with the plural here suggesting perhaps it and its canals> to blood so they could not drink [from] their streams.
passages.78:45: He sent among them flies that devoured them and frogs that destroyed them.
passages.78:46: And he gave their crop to the locusts and their labor to the locust.<note: Two different words translated "locusts">
passages.78:47: He destroyed their vines with hail and their sycamore trees with sleet.<note: The word for "sleet" is only used here, and the translation is a guess based on context>
passages.78:48: He also handed their cattle over to the hail and their livestock to the lightning bolts.
passages.78:49: He sent against them his fierce anger, rage and indignation and trouble, a band of {destroying}<note: Literally "evil"> angels.
passages.78:50: He cleared a path for his anger. He did not spare them<note: Hebrew "their soul"> from death but handed their life over to the plague.
passages.78:51: And he struck down all [the] firstborn in Egypt, [the] first of [their] virility in the tents of Ham.
passages.78:52: Then he led out his people like sheep and guided them like a herd in the wilderness.
passages.78:53: And he led them safely and they were not afraid, but the sea covered their enemies.
passages.78:54: So he brought them to his holy territory,<note: Hebrew "border"> this mountain his right hand acquired.<note: Or "had created">
passages.78:55: And he drove out nations before them and allocated them for an inheritance by [boundary] line, and settled the tribes of Israel in their tents.
passages.78:56: But they tested and rebelled against God Most High and did not keep his statutes.
passages.78:57: And they turned and were treacherous like their ancestors.<note: Or "fathers"> They twisted like a crooked<note: Or "deceitful"> bow.
passages.78:58: For they provoked him to anger with their high places, and made him jealous with their images.
passages.78:59: God heard and he was very angry and rejected Israel utterly.
passages.78:60: So he abandoned the dwelling place at Shiloh, [the] tent he had placed among humankind.
passages.78:61: And he gave his strength into captivity and his splendor into [the] hand of [the] enemy.
passages.78:62: He also handed his people over to the sword, and he was very angry with his inheritance.
passages.78:63: Fire devoured his young men, and his young women<note: Or "virgins"> were not praised.
passages.78:64: His priests fell by the sword, and his widows did not weep.
passages.78:65: Then the Lord awoke like [one who had been] asleep, [awoke] like a warrior who had been drunk with wine.<note: Or "like a warrior shouting because of wine">
passages.78:66: And he beat back his enemies; he gave them over to perpetual scorn.
passages.78:67: And he rejected the tent of Joseph, and did not chose the tribe of Ephraim,
passages.78:68: but chose the tribe of Judah, {Mount Zion}<note: Literally "the mountain of Zion"> that he loved.
passages.78:69: And he built his sanctuary like [the] heights, like [the] earth that he established forever.
passages.78:70: And he chose David his servant and took him from [the] sheepfolds.
passages.78:71: He brought him from following nursing ewes to shepherd Jacob, his people, and Israel, his inheritance.
passages.78:72: And he shepherded them according to the integrity of his heart, and led them by the skillfulness of his hands.
passages.79:title: A psalm of Asaph.<note: The Hebrew Bible counts the superscription as the first verse of the psalm>
passages.79:1: O God, [the] nations have entered your inheritance; they have defiled your holy temple; they have reduced Jerusalem to ruins.
passages.79:2: They have given the bodies of your servants as food for the birds of the heavens, the flesh of your faithful to [the] beasts of [the] earth.
passages.79:3: They have poured out their blood like water all around Jerusalem, and there was none to bury [them].
passages.79:4: We have become a taunt to our neighbors, a derision and a scorn to those around us.
passages.79:5: How long, O Yahweh? Will you be angry forever? Will your jealousy burn like fire?
passages.79:6: Pour out your anger on the nations that do not know you, and on [the] kingdoms that do not call on your name,
passages.79:7: because they<note: Hebrew "he"> have devoured Jacob and have laid waste his habitation.
passages.79:8: Do not remember against us former iniquities; let your mercies meet us quickly because we are brought very low.
passages.79:9: Help us, O God of our salvation, for the glory of your name; and deliver us and forgive<note: Hebrew "make atonement for"> our sins for the sake of your name.
passages.79:10: Why should the nations say, "Where [is] their God?" Let it<note: That is, God's name> be known among the nations before our eyes, [by] the avenging of the blood of your servants that was poured out.
passages.79:11: Let the groaning of the prisoner come before you. According to the greatness of your {power},<note: Literally "arm"> spare<note: Or "leave a remnant of"> [the] children [appointed to] death.
passages.79:12: And return to our neighbors sevenfold {upon them}<note: Hebrew "into their bosom"> their taunts [with] which they taunted you, O Lord.
passages.79:13: Then we, your people and the flock of your pasture, we will give thanks to you forever. {Generation after generation}<note: Literally "to a generation and a generation"> we will tell of your praise.
passages.80:title: For the [music] director, according to [The] Lilies. A testimony. Of Asaph. A psalm.<note: The Hebrew Bible counts the superscription as the first verse of the psalm; the English verse number is reduced by one>
passages.80:1: Give ear, O shepherd of Israel, [who] leads Joseph like a flock. Shine forth, [you who] sits [enthroned above] the cherubim.
passages.80:2: Before Ephraim, Benjamin, and Manasseh, stir up your power and come for our salvation.
passages.80:3: O God, restore us, and cause your face to shine that we may be saved.
passages.80:4: O Yahweh God [of] hosts, {how long will you be angry}<note: Literally "until when [your anger] smoke"> against the prayer of your people?
passages.80:5: You have fed them [the] bread of tears; you have given them tears to drink in full measure.<note: The Hebrew "threefold" or "a third of a measure" is difficult>
passages.80:6: You have made us [an object of] strife to our neighbors, and our enemies mock among themselves.
passages.80:7: O God [of] hosts, restore us and cause your face to shine that we may be saved.
passages.80:8: You uprooted a vine from Egypt; you drove out [the] nations and planted it.
passages.80:9: You prepared [a place] before it, and {it took deep root}<note: Literally "its root rooted"> and filled [the] land.
passages.80:10: [The] mountains were covered with its shade, and [the] mighty cedars [with] its boughs.
passages.80:11: It spread its branches to [the] sea and its shoots to [the] river.
passages.80:12: Why have you broken down its walls, so that all [who] pass on [the] road pluck [fruit from] it?
passages.80:13: Swine from the forests devour<note: Hebrew "devours"> it and creatures of [the] field feed on it.
passages.80:14: Please return, O God [of] hosts. Observe from heaven and see, and pay attention to this vine,
passages.80:15: even[the] stalk that your right hand planted, and concerning [the] shoot<note: Hebrew "son"> you strengthened for yourself.
passages.80:16: [It is] burned with fire, cut down. They perish at the rebuke of your face.
passages.80:17: Let your hand be on the man of your right hand, on [the] son of humankind [whom] you made strong for yourself.
passages.80:18: Then we will not turn back from you. Restore us to life, and we will proclaim your name.
passages.80:19: O Yahweh God [of] hosts, restore us; cause your face to shine that we may be saved.
passages.81:title: For the [music] director; on the Gittith. Of Asaph.<note: The Hebrew Bible counts the superscription as the first verse of the psalm; the English verse number is reduced by one>
passages.81:1: Shout out to God our strength; shout joyfully to the God of Jacob.
passages.81:2: Lift up a song and strike<note: Hebrew "give"> [the] tambourine, [the] pleasant lyre, together with [the] harp.
passages.81:3: Blow [the] horn at new moon, at full moon, for our feast day,
passages.81:4: because it [is] a statute for Israel, an ordinance of the God of Jacob.
passages.81:5: He made it a statute<note: Hebrew "testimony" or "witness"> in Joseph when he went out against the land of Egypt, [where] I heard a language I did not know.<note: The meaning of this line is uncertain. The above is based on perhaps a similar thought in Psa 114:1>
passages.81:6: "I removed his shoulder from a burden. His hands were freed from [the] basket.
passages.81:7: In this<note: Hebrew "the"> trouble you called, and I rescued you. Within [the] secret place of thunder I answered you; I tested you at the waters of Meribah. Selah
passages.81:8: Hear, O my people, and I will admonish you; O Israel, if you would [but] listen to me.
passages.81:9: There shall be no strange god among you, and you shall not bow down to a foreign god.
passages.81:10: I [am] Yahweh your God, who brought you up from the land of Egypt. Open wide your mouth and I will fill it.
passages.81:11: But my people did not listen to my voice, and Israel did not yield to me.
passages.81:12: So I let them<note: Hebrew "him"> go in the stubbornness of their heart; they walked in their counsels.
passages.81:13: Oh that my people would listen to me; [that] Israel would walk in my ways.
passages.81:14: I would subdue their enemies quickly, and turn my hand against their adversaries.
passages.81:15: Those who hate Yahweh would cringe before him, and their fate<note: Hebrew "time"> would be forever.
passages.81:16: But he would feed him<note: That is, Israel> from [the] choicest wheat,<note: Hebrew "[the] fat of wheat"> and I would satisfy you with honey from a rock."
passages.82:title: A psalm of Asaph.<note: The Hebrew Bible counts the superscription as the first verse of the psalm>
passages.82:1: God stands in the divine assembly;<note: Or "assembly of El "> he administers judgment in the midst of [the] gods.<note: Hebrew elohim>
passages.82:2: "How long will you judge unjustly and {show favoritism to the wicked}?<note: Literally "lift up the faces of the wicked"> Selah
passages.82:3: Judge [on behalf of the] helpless and [the] orphan; provide justice [to the] afflicted and [the] poor.
passages.82:4: Rescue [the] helpless and [the] needy; deliver [them] from the hand of [the] wicked."
passages.82:5: They do not know or consider.<note: Or "understand"> They go about in the darkness, [so that] all [the] foundations of [the] earth are shaken.
passages.82:6: I have said,<note: Hebrew "I, I have said"> "You [are] gods, and sons of the Most High, all of you.
passages.82:7: However, you will die like men,<note: Singular> and you will fall like one of the princes."
passages.82:8: Rise up, O God, judge the earth, because you shall inherit<note: Or "receive an inheritance"> all the nations.
passages.83:title: A song. A psalm of Asaph.<note: The Hebrew Bible counts the superscription as the first verse of the psalm; the English verse number is reduced by one>
passages.83:1: O God, do not rest [silently]. Do not keep silent or be still, O God.
passages.83:2: For look, your enemies roar, and those who hate you have lifted [their] head.
passages.83:3: They devise cunning schemes<note: Hebrew "scheme"> against your people, and consult together against your protected ones.<note: Or "your treasured ones">
passages.83:4: They say, "Come, let us annihilate them from [being] a nation, so that the name of Israel will be remembered no more."
passages.83:5: For they have consulted together {with a unified purpose}.<note: Literally "with a heart together"> They have made a covenant against you:
passages.83:6: the tents of Edom and [the] Ishmaelites, Moab and [the] Hagrites,
passages.83:7: Gebal and Ammon and Amalek, Philistia, with the inhabitants of Tyre.
passages.83:8: Assyria also has joined with them. They {provide help}<note: Literally "they have become an arm for"> to the children of Lot. Selah
passages.83:9: Do to them as [you did with] Midian, as [with] Sisera, as [with] Jabin at the wadi of Kishon.
passages.83:10: They were destroyed at En-dor; they became dung for the ground.
passages.83:11: Make their leaders like Oreb and Zeeb, and all their chiefs like Zebah and Zalmunna,
passages.83:12: who said, "Let us take [as] our possession the pastures of God."
passages.83:13: O my God, make them like the tumbleweed, like the chaff before wind.
passages.83:14: As fire burns a forest, and as a flame sets afire mountains,
passages.83:15: so pursue them with your tempest and terrify them with your storm.
passages.83:16: Fill their faces with shame, that they may seek your name, O Yahweh.
passages.83:17: Let them be ashamed and terrified forever, and let them be humiliated and perish
passages.83:18: that they may know that you, [whose] name [is] Yahweh, you alone, [are the] Most High over the whole earth.
passages.84:title: For the [music] director; on the Gittith. Of the sons of Korah. A psalm.<note: The Hebrew Bible counts the superscription as the first verse of the psalm; the English verse number is reduced by one>
passages.84:1: How lovely [are] your dwelling places, O Yahweh of hosts!
passages.84:2: My soul longs and even fails for the courtyards of Yahweh. My heart and flesh sing for joy to the living God.
passages.84:3: Even a bird finds a home, and a swallow a nest for herself, where she may lay her young, near your altars, O Yahweh [of] hosts, my king and my God.
passages.84:4: Blessed [are] those who dwell in your house;<note: Or "temple"> they can ever praise you. Selah
passages.84:5: Blessed [is the] man whose strength [is] in you; in their heart [are the] highways [to Zion].
passages.84:6: Passing through the Valley of Baca,<note: Or "Valley of Weeping"> they make it a spring. The early rain covers [it with] blessings<note: A change in vocalization of the Hebrew yields "[it with] pools"> as well.
passages.84:7: They go from strength to strength, [until each] appears before God in Zion.<note: Or "the God of gods will be seen in Zion">
passages.84:8: O Yahweh, God of hosts, hear my prayer; give ear, O God of Jacob. Selah
passages.84:9: Look at our shield, O God, and have regard for the face of your anointed one.
passages.84:10: Because better [is] a day in your courtyards than a thousand [elsewhere]. I would rather be at the threshold of the house<note: Or "temple"> of my God than to dwell in [the] tents of wickedness.
passages.84:11: Because Yahweh God [is] a sun and a shield; Yahweh gives grace and honor. He does not withhold good from those who walk blamelessly.
passages.84:12: O Yahweh [of] hosts, blessed [is the] man who trusts you.
passages.85:title: For the [music] director. Of the sons of Korah. A psalm.<note: The Hebrew Bible counts the superscription as the first verse of the psalm; the English verse number is reduced by one>
passages.85:1: O Yahweh, you favored your land. You restored the fortunes<note: Or "captivity"> of Jacob.
passages.85:2: You took away the guilt<note: Or "You forgave the iniquity"> of your people; you covered all their sin. Selah
passages.85:3: You withdrew all your wrath; you turned from your burning anger.
passages.85:4: Restore us, O God of our salvation, and annul your vexation with us.
passages.85:5: Will you be angry against us forever? Will you prolong your anger generation after generation?
passages.85:6: Will you not again revive us, that your people might rejoice in you?
passages.85:7: Show us, O Yahweh, your loyal love, and grant us your salvation.
passages.85:8: I will hear what God, Yahweh, will speak, because he will speak peace to his people, even his faithful [ones],<note: Hebrew "and to his faithful"> but let them not return to folly.
passages.85:9: Surely his salvation [is] near for those who fear him, that glory may abide in our land.
passages.85:10: Loyal love and faithfulness<note: Or "truth"> will meet one another; righteousness and peace will kiss.
passages.85:11: Faithfulness<note: Or "Truth"> will sprout from [the] ground, and righteousness will look down from heaven.
passages.85:12: Yes, Yahweh will give [what is] good, and our land will give its produce.
passages.85:13: Righteousness will go before him, and it will make his steps a pathway.
passages.86:title: A prayer of David.<note: The Hebrew Bible counts the superscription as the first verse of the psalm>
passages.86:1: Incline, O Yahweh, your ear [and] answer me, because I [am] poor and needy.
passages.86:2: Watch over my life because I [am] faithful. You [are] my God; save your servant. [I am] the one who trusts you.
passages.86:3: Be gracious to me, O Lord, because I call to you {all day long}.<note: Literally "all the day">
passages.86:4: Make glad the soul of your servant, because {I desire you},<note: Literally "I lift up my soul to you"> O Lord.
passages.86:5: For you, O Lord, [are] good and forgiving, and abundant in loyal love<note: Hebrew "and great with respect to loyal love"> for all who call to you.
passages.86:6: Heed, O Yahweh, my prayer, and attend to the voice of my supplications.
passages.86:7: In the day of my trouble I call to you, because you answer me.
passages.86:8: There is none like you among the gods, O Lord, and there are no works like yours.
passages.86:9: All [the] nations that you have made will come and bow down<note: Or "worship"> before you, O Lord, and glorify your name.
passages.86:10: For you [are] great and doing wondrous things; you alone [are] God.
passages.86:11: Teach me, O Yahweh, your way, [that] I may walk in your truth. Unite my heart<note: That is, give singleness of heart> to fear your name.
passages.86:12: I will give you thanks, O Lord my God, with all my heart, and glorify your name forever,
passages.86:13: because your loyal love [is] great toward me, and you will have delivered my life from Sheol<note: The nether world, the place of departed spirits.> below.
passages.86:14: O God, arrogant men have risen up against me, even a gang of ruthless men seek my life, but they do not set you before them.<note: That is, they do not factor God into their actions>
passages.86:15: But you, O Lord, [are] a compassionate and gracious God, {slow to anger}<note: Literally "long of nostrils"> and abundant in loyal love and faithfulness.
passages.86:16: Turn to me and be gracious to me. Give your strength to your servant, and grant victory to the son<note: Or "Save the son"> of your maidservant.
passages.86:17: Do a sign [that] benefits me, that those who hate me may see and be put to shame, because you, O Yahweh, have helped me and comforted me.
passages.87:title: Of the sons of Korah. A psalm. A song.<note: The Hebrew Bible counts the superscription as the first verse of the psalm>
passages.87:2: Yahweh loves the gates of Zion more than all the dwellings of Jacob.
passages.87:3: Glorious things [are] spoken about<note: Or "in"> you, O city of God. Selah
passages.87:4: I will record<note: Or "mention"> those who know me [in] Rahab<note: That is, Egypt; compare Isa 30:7> and Babylon, behold [in] Philistia and Tyre with Cush, "This one was born there."
passages.87:5: But with respect to Zion it shall be said, "{Each one}<note: Literally "A man and a man"> was born in her," for the Most High himself will establish her.
passages.87:6: Yahweh will record in writing [the] peoples, "This [one] was born there." Selah
passages.87:7: And while dancing, singers [will sing], "All my springs [are] in you."
passages.88:title: A song. A psalm of the sons of Korah. For the [music] director; according to Mahalath Leannoth. A maskil of Heman the Ezrahite.<note: The Hebrew Bible counts the superscription as the first verse of the psalm; the English verse number is reduced by one>
passages.88:1: O Yahweh, God of my salvation, I cry out by day [and] through the night before you.
passages.88:2: Let my prayer come before you; incline your ear to my cry.
passages.88:3: For my soul is full with troubles, and my life approaches Sheol.
passages.88:4: I am reckoned with [those] descending to [the] pit. I am like a man<note: The Hebrew suggests a strong, vigorous man> without strength,<note: Or "without help">
passages.88:5: set free<note: Or "forsaken"> among the dead, like [the] slain lying in [the] grave, whom you no longer remember, even those cut off from your hand.
passages.88:6: You have set me in [the] pit below, in dark places, in [the] depths.
passages.88:7: Your wrath presses upon me, and you afflict [me with] all your waves. Selah
passages.88:8: You have removed my acquaintances far from me. You have made me detestable<note: Hebrew "an abomination"> to them. [I am] confined and cannot go out.
passages.88:9: My eye languishes from misery. I call on you, O Yahweh, every day; I spread out my hands<note: Hebrew "palms"> to you.
passages.88:10: Do you work wonders<note: Hebrew "wonder"> for the dead? Or do [the] departed spirits<note: Hebrew rephaim, sometimes translated "shades"; the weakened state of those who have died> rise up [to] praise you? Selah
passages.88:11: Is your loyal love told in the grave, [or] your faithfulness in the underworld?<note: Hebrew abaddon, the place of destruction>
passages.88:12: Are your wonders<note: Hebrew "wonder"> known in the darkness, [or] your righteousness<note: Or "deed of justice"> in [the] land of forgetfulness?
passages.88:13: But as for me, I cry for help to you, O Yahweh, and in the morning my prayer comes before you.
passages.88:14: Why do you reject my soul, O Yahweh? [Why] do you hide your face from me?
passages.88:15: I [am] afflicted and perishing from [my] youth. I bear your terrors. I am distraught.<note: Hebrew meaning uncertain>
passages.88:16: Your burning anger has passed over me; your sudden fears have destroyed me.
passages.88:17: They surround me like water all the day; they circle about me altogether.
passages.88:18: You have removed loved one and friend far from me, my acquaintances [far from my] darkness.
passages.89:title: A maskil of Ethan the Ezrahite.<note: The Hebrew Bible counts the superscription as the first verse of the psalm; the English verse number is reduced by one>
passages.89:1: I will sing forever of Yahweh's acts of loyal love. {From generation to generation}<note: Literally "To a generation and a generation"> I will make known your faithfulness with my mouth.
passages.89:2: For I say, "Forever [your] loyal love is built up. [The] heavens you have established [with] your faithfulness in them."
passages.89:3: "I made a covenant with my chosen one; I swore [an oath] to David my servant:
passages.89:4: 'I will establish your descendants forever, and I will build up your throne {from generation to generation}.'"<note: Literally "To a generation and a generation"> Selah
passages.89:5: And [so the] heavens will praise your wonderful deed, O Yahweh, even your faithfulness, in [the] assembly of [the] holy ones.
passages.89:6: For who in the sky<note: Hebrew singular collective "clouds"> is equal to Yahweh? [Who is] like Yahweh among the sons of God,
passages.89:7: a God feared greatly in the council of [the] holy ones, and awesome above all surrounding him?
passages.89:8: O Yahweh God [of] hosts, who [is] mighty like you, O Yah, with<note: Hebrew "and"> your faithfulness surrounding you?
passages.89:9: You are ruling the surging of the sea. When its waves rise, {you yourself still}<note: Literally "you, you calm"> them.
passages.89:10: {You yourself crushed}<note: Literally "You, you crushed"> Rahab like one [who is] slain; you scattered your enemies with your strong arm.
passages.89:11: [The] heavens are yours, [the] earth yours as well, [the] world with its fullness, [because] you founded them.
passages.89:12: North and south, you created them; Tabor and Hermon shout joyfully over your name.
passages.89:13: You have a mighty arm; Your hand is strong; your right hand reaches high.
passages.89:14: Righteousness and justice [are] the foundation of your throne. Loyal love and faithfulness<note: Or "truth"> come before your face.<note: That is, enjoy continual access>
passages.89:15: Blessed [are] the people who know [the] joyful shout; O Yahweh, they walk about in the light of your countenance.
passages.89:16: In your name they rejoice all the day, and in your righteousness they rise up.
passages.89:17: For you [are] the glory of their strength, and by your favor our horn rises up,<note: According to the reading tradition (Qere). The Kethib reads "you exalt our horn">
passages.89:18: because our shield belongs to Yahweh,<note: Or "Yahweh [is] our shield."> and our king to the Holy One of Israel.<note: Or "The Holy One of Israel [is] our king.">
passages.89:19: Formerly you spoke in a vision to your faithful ones, and said, "I have bestowed help on a mighty man; I have exalted one chosen from [the] people.
passages.89:20: I have found David, my servant. With my holy oil I have anointed him,
passages.89:21: with whom my hand will be steadfast. Surely my arm will strengthen him.
passages.89:22: [The] enemy will not deceive him, and no {evil man}<note: Literally "a son of wickedness"> will afflict him.
passages.89:23: But I will crush his adversaries before him, and I will strike those who hate him.
passages.89:24: And [so] my faithfulness and my loyal love [will be] with him, and in my name his horn will rise up.
passages.89:25: And I will set his hand on the sea and his right hand on the rivers.
passages.89:26: He will call out [to] me, 'You [are] my Father, my God, and the rock of my salvation.'
passages.89:27: I will also make him [the] firstborn, [the] highest of [the] kings of [the] earth.
passages.89:28: Forever I will keep my loyal love for him, and my covenant [will be] reliable for him.
passages.89:29: I will also establish his offspring forever, and his throne as [the] days of [the] heavens.
passages.89:30: If his sons forsake my law and do not walk in my judgments,
passages.89:31: if they defile<note: Hebrew "profane; treat as common"> my statutes and do not keep my commandments,
passages.89:32: then I will punish their transgression with [a] rod, and their guilt with wounds.
passages.89:33: But I will not break off my loyal love from him, and I will not be false against my faithfulness.
passages.89:34: I will not defile<note: Hebrew "profane; treat as common"> my covenant, or alter what proceeded from my lips.
passages.89:35: Once<note: Hebrew "One"> I have sworn by my holiness, 'I will surely not lie to David,
passages.89:36: His offspring will endure<note: Hebrew "be"> forever, and his throne as the sun before me.
passages.89:37: Like [the] moon it will be steadfast forever, and [like] an enduring witness in the sky.'" Selah
passages.89:38: But you have spurned and rejected; you are very angry with your anointed one.
passages.89:39: You have repudiated the covenant with your servant; you have defiled<note: Hebrew "profane; treat as common"> his crown in<note: Hebrew "to"> the dirt.
passages.89:40: You have broken down all his walls; you have made his fortifications a ruin.
passages.89:41: All passing along [the] road plunder him; he has become a taunt to his neighbors.
passages.89:42: You have raised the right hand<note: That is, given them victory> of his adversaries. You have made all his enemies rejoice.
passages.89:43: You have also turned back the edge of his sword and have not helped him stand [his ground] in the battle.
passages.89:44: You have made his splendor to cease, and cast his throne to the ground.
passages.89:45: You have cut short the days of his youth; you have covered him with shame. Selah
passages.89:46: How long, O Yahweh? Will you hide yourself forever? Will your wrath burn like fire [forever]?
passages.89:47: Remember what my lifespan [is]. [Remember] for what vanity you have created all [the] children of humankind.
passages.89:48: What man can live [on] and not see death? Can he deliver his life from the {power}<note: Literally "hand""> of Sheol? Selah
passages.89:49: Where [are] your former acts of loyal love, O Lord, [that] you swore to David by your faithfulness?
passages.89:50: Remember, O Lord the taunting of your servants, [how] I bear in my bosom [the taunts of] all [the] many peoples,
passages.89:51: [by] which your enemies taunt, O Yahweh, [by] which they taunt the steps of your anointed one.
passages.89:52: Blessed be Yahweh forever. Amen and Amen.
passages.90:title: A prayer of Moses, the man of God.<note: The Hebrew Bible counts the superscription as the first verse of the psalm>
passages.90:1: O Lord, you have been our help<note: Or "dwelling place"> {in all generations}.<note: Literally "in a generation and a generation">
passages.90:2: Before [the] mountains were born and you brought forth [the] earth and [the] world, even from everlasting to everlasting, you [are] God.
passages.90:3: You return man to [the] dust, {saying},<note: Literally "and you say"> "Return, O sons of man."
passages.90:4: For a thousand years in your eyes [are] like yesterday when it passes, or [like] a watch in the night.
passages.90:5: You sweep them away [like a flood]. They fall asleep.<note: The interpretation of 5a is difficult> In the morning [they are] like grass [that] sprouts anew.
passages.90:6: In the morning it blossoms and sprouts anew; by evening it withers and dries up.
passages.90:7: For we are brought to an end by your anger, and we hasten [off]<note: Or "we are terrified"> by your wrath.
passages.90:8: You have put our iniquities before you, our hidden [sins] into the light of your countenance.
passages.90:9: For all of our days dwindle away in your rage; we complete our years like a sigh.
passages.90:10: As for the days of our years, within them [are] seventy years or if by strength eighty years, and their pride<note: Or "span"> [is] trouble and disaster, for it passes quickly and we fly [away].
passages.90:11: Who knows the strength of your anger, and your rage consistent with<note: Hebrew "according to"> [the] fear due you?
passages.90:12: So teach [us] to number our days that we may gain a heart of wisdom.
passages.90:13: Return,<note: Or "Turn back [your wrath]"> O Yahweh. How long? And have compassion on<note: Or "change your mind concerning"> your servants.
passages.90:14: Satisfy us in the morning with your loyal love, that we may sing for joy and be glad all our days.
passages.90:15: Make us glad for as many days as you have afflicted us, [for as many] years [as] we have seen calamity.
passages.90:16: Let your work be visible to your servants, and your majesty to their children.
passages.90:17: And let the beauty of the Lord our God be upon us, and establish for us the work of our hands, yes, the work of our hands, establish it.
passages.91:1: [One who] lives in the secret place<note: Or "shelter"> of the Most High will lodge in the shadow of Shaddai.<note: Often translated "the Almighty," this is perhaps better understood as "[God of the] Mountain">
passages.91:2: I will say to Yahweh, "[You are] my refuge and my fortress, my God [in whom] I trust."
passages.91:3: For he will deliver<note: Hebrew "he, he will deliver" is perhaps emphatic, "He will certainly deliver"> you from [the] snare of [the] fowler, from [the] plague of destruction.
passages.91:4: With his feathers he will cover you, and under his wings you can take refuge. His faithfulness [will be] a shield and a buckler.<note: That is, a small, round shield, or perhaps a surrounding bulwark>
passages.91:5: You need not fear [the] terror of [the] night, [or the] arrow [that] flies by day,
passages.91:6: [or the] plague [that] spreads in the darkness, [or the] destruction [that] devastates at noon.
passages.91:7: A thousand may fall at your side, and ten thousand at your right [hand], [but] it will not come near you.
passages.91:8: You will only look with your eyes, and see [the] punishment of [the] wicked.
passages.91:9: For you, O Yahweh, [are] my refuge. You have made the Most High your dwelling place.<note: This is the most straightforward translation of the Hebrew, though the "you" of each line would refer to a different person. A more unusual rendering would be "Because Yahweh, my refuge, even the Most High, you have made your dwelling place ...">
passages.91:10: No harm will befall you, and no plague will come near your tent.
passages.91:11: For he will command his angels concerning you, to watch over you in all your ways.
passages.91:12: In [their] hands they will bear you up, lest you strike your foot against a stone.
passages.91:13: You will tread on lion and viper; you will trample young lion and serpent.
passages.91:14: Because he loves me, therefore I will deliver him; I will protect<note: The sense is that of making something inaccessibly high, like a fortress> him because he knows my name.
passages.91:15: He will call upon me and I will answer him; I [will be] with him in trouble; I will rescue and honor him.
passages.91:16: [With] {long life}<note: Literally "a length of days"> I will satisfy him, and show him my salvation.
passages.92:title: A psalm. A song. For the Sabbath day.<note: The Hebrew Bible counts the superscription as the first verse of the psalm; the English verse number is reduced by one>
passages.92:1: [It is] good to give thanks to Yahweh, and to sing praise concerning your name, O Most High;
passages.92:2: to declare in the morning your loyal love and your faithfulness in the night,
passages.92:3: on [the] ten [string], and on [the] harp, with a melody on [the] lyre.
passages.92:4: For you, O Yahweh, have made me glad by your work; by the deeds of your hands I sing for joy.
passages.92:5: How great are your deeds, O Yahweh; [how] very deep are your thoughts.
passages.92:6: [The] brutish man does not know, and [the] fool cannot understand this.
passages.92:7: When the wicked flourish like grass and all [the] workers of evil blossom, [it is] so they can be destroyed forever.
passages.92:8: But you [are] on high forever, O Yahweh.
passages.92:9: For behold, your enemies, O Yahweh, for behold, your enemies will perish. All [the] workers of evil will be scattered.
passages.92:10: But you have exalted my horn like [that of] a wild ox; you have anointed me<note: The Hebrew's "[that] I have moistened with fresh oil" seems unlikely. The above translation presupposes the loss of a letter in the Hebrew textual tradition (ballotani for the MT's balloti)> with fresh oil.
passages.92:11: And [so] my eye looks on my enemies.<note: This word for "enemies" suggests those watching for any advantage> My ears hear those evildoers who rise up against me.
passages.92:12: [The] righteous<note: Hebrew singular, but used as a collective. The verbs of this verse are also singular> will flourish like the date palm. They will grow like a cedar in Lebanon.
passages.92:13: Planted in the house<note: Or "temple"> of Yahweh, they will flourish in the courts of our God.
passages.92:14: They will still prosper in old age. They will be fat and luxuriant,<note: This is the same word used of the oil in v. 11 and translated "fresh">
passages.92:15: to declare that Yahweh [is] upright. [He is] my rock, and [there is] no injustice<note: According to the reading tradition (Qere)> in him.
passages.93:1: Yahweh is king; he clothes himself with majesty. Yahweh clothes himself; he girds himself with might. Yes, [the] world is established [so that] it will not be moved.
passages.93:2: Your throne [is] established from of old; you [are] from everlasting.
passages.93:3: [The] rivers have lifted up, O Yahweh; [the] rivers have lifted up their {rumbling};<note: Literally "voice"> [the] rivers have lifted up their pounding.
passages.93:4: [Mightier] than the rumblings of many waters, [mightier] than [the] mighty breakers of [the] sea, Yahweh on high [is] mighty.
passages.93:5: Your testimonies are fully reliable. Holiness is fitting for your house,<note: Or "temple"> O Yahweh, {forever}.<note: Literally "for a length of days">
passages.94:1: O Yahweh, God of vengeance, God of vengeance, shine forth.
passages.94:2: Rise up, O Judge of the earth. Repay upon the proud what is [their] rightful due.
passages.94:3: How long [will the] wicked, O Yahweh, how long will [the] wicked exult?
passages.94:4: {They gush words}<note: Literally "They gush, they speak," which is probably a hendiadys> unrestrained. All [the] evildoers boast.
passages.94:5: They crush your people, O Yahweh; they oppress your inheritance.
passages.94:6: They kill widow and stranger, and they murder orphans,
passages.94:7: while<note: Hebrew "and"> they say, "Yah<note: A shortened form of "Yahweh"> does not see," and "The God of Jacob does not pay attention."
passages.94:8: You pay attention, O brutes among the people. And [you] fools, when you will show insight?
passages.94:9: Will [the] one who planted [the] ear not hear? Will [the] one who formed [the] eye not see?
passages.94:10: Will [the] one who instructs nations not rebuke, the one who teaches humankind knowledge?
passages.94:11: Yahweh knows [the] thoughts of humankind, that {they [are] to no purpose}.<note: Literally "they [are] a breath" or "a vanity">
passages.94:12: Blessed [is] the man, O Yah, whom you instruct and teach from your law,
passages.94:13: to give him rest from days of trouble, until a pit is dug for the wicked.
passages.94:14: For Yahweh will not abandon his people, nor forsake his inheritance.
passages.94:15: For judgment will return to righteousness,<note: That is, the court system will operate correctly> and all the upright in heart [will follow] after it.
passages.94:16: Who rose up for me against [the] wicked? Who stood up for me against [the] workers of iniquity?
passages.94:17: If Yahweh had not been my help, my soul would soon have dwelt in silence.
passages.94:18: When I thought,<note: Hebrew "If/When I said," that is, said to myself> "My foot is slipping," your loyal love, O Yahweh, supported me.
passages.94:19: When my troubled thoughts were many {within me},<note: Literally "in my inward parts"> your consolations cheered my soul.
passages.94:20: Can there be allied with you a throne of destruction, one that forms trouble based on statute?
passages.94:21: They band together against [the] life of [the] righteous, and declare [the] blameless guilty of blood.<note: Or "condemn innocent blood">
passages.94:22: But Yahweh has become my [high] stronghold, and my God [has become] my rock of refuge.
passages.94:23: And he will repay on them their iniquity, and by<note: Or "in"> their evil he will destroy them. Yahweh our God will destroy them.
passages.95:1: Come, let us sing for joy to Yahweh; let us shout joyfully to the rock of our salvation.
passages.95:2: Let us come before his presence with thanksgiving; with songs let us shout joyfully to him.
passages.95:3: For Yahweh [is] [the]<note: The Hebrew does not have the definite article used twice in the translation of this verse> great God, and [the] great king over all gods,
passages.95:4: in whose hand [are the] unexplored places<note: Or "the deep places"> of [the] earth, and [the] heights of [the] mountains [are] his,
passages.95:5: to whom belongs the sea that he made, <note: Hebrew "and he made it"> and [the] dry land [that] his hands formed.
passages.95:6: Come in, let us worship and bow down; let us kneel before Yahweh, our maker.
passages.95:7: For he [is] our God, and we [are] the people of his pasture and the sheep of his hand. {Today}<note: Literally "The day"> if you will hear his voice:<note: Or "If only you would hear his voice today">
passages.95:8: "Do not harden your heart as [at] Meribah, as [in] the day of Massah in the wilderness,
passages.95:9: when your ancestors<note: Or "fathers"> tried me. They put me to the test, [even] though they had seen my work.
passages.95:10: For forty years I loathed [that] generation, and said, '[They are] a people [whose] heart wanders. And my ways they do not know.'
passages.95:11: Therefore I swore in my anger, 'They shall surely not enter into my rest.'"
passages.96:1: Sing to<note: Or "concerning"> Yahweh a new song; sing to<note: Or "concerning"> Yahweh, all the earth.
passages.96:2: Sing to<note: Or "concerning"> Yahweh; bless his name. Announce<note: Or "bring good news concerning"> his salvation from day to day.
passages.96:3: Tell his glory among the nations, his marvelous works among all the peoples.
passages.96:4: For Yahweh [is] great and very worthy of praise; he [is to be] feared above all gods.
passages.96:5: For all the gods of the peoples [are] idols,<note: This word for idols suggests something worthless or insignificant> but Yahweh made [the] heavens.
passages.96:6: Splendor and majesty [are] before him; strength and beauty [are] in his sanctuary.
passages.96:7: Ascribe to Yahweh, you families of [the] peoples, ascribe to Yahweh glory and strength.
passages.96:8: Ascribe to Yahweh the glory due his name; bring an offering and come into his courts.
passages.96:9: Worship Yahweh in holy array; tremble before him, all the earth.
passages.96:10: Say among the nations, "Yahweh is king! Yes, [the] world is established [so that] it will not be moved. He will judge [the] peoples fairly."
passages.96:11: Let the heavens be glad and the earth rejoice. Let the sea with<note: Hebrew "and"> its fullness roar.
passages.96:12: Let [the] field with<note: Hebrew "and"> all that [is] in it exult. Then all [the] trees of [the] forests will sing for joy
passages.96:13: before Yahweh, for he is coming; for he is coming to judge the earth. He will judge [the] world with righteousness, and [the] peoples with his faithfulness.
passages.97:1: Yahweh is king! Let the earth rejoice; let many coastlands be glad.
passages.97:2: Cloud and thick darkness [are] surrounding him; righteousness and justice [are] the foundation of his throne.
passages.97:3: Fire goes before him, and devours his enemies round about.
passages.97:4: His lightnings light [the] world; the earth sees and trembles.
passages.97:5: [The] mountains melt like wax at the presence of Yahweh, at the presence of the Lord of all the earth.
passages.97:6: The heavens declare his righteousness, and all the peoples see his glory.
passages.97:7: Let all who serve an image be ashamed, those who boast about idols.<note: This word for idols suggests something worthless or insignificant> Worship him, all you gods.
passages.97:8: Zion hears and is glad, and the daughters of Judah rejoice because of your judgments, O Yahweh.
passages.97:9: For you, O Yahweh, [are] most high over all the earth. You are highly<note: Hebrew "very"> exalted above all gods.
passages.97:10: You who love Yahweh, hate evil. He protects the lives of his faithful; he delivers them from [the] hand of [the] wicked.
passages.97:11: Light [is] sown for the righteous, and joy for [the] upright in heart.
passages.97:12: Be glad in Yahweh, [you] righteous, and give thanks {to his holy name}.<note: Literally "to his holy remembrance" or "to his memorable holiness">
passages.98:title: A psalm.<note: The Hebrew Bible counts the superscription as the first verse of the psalm>
passages.98:1: Sing to<note: Or "sing concerning"> Yahweh a new song, for he has done wonders. His right hand and his holy arm have secured his victory.
passages.98:2: Yahweh has made known his salvation;<note: Or "victory"> to the eyes of the nations he has revealed his righteousness.
passages.98:3: He has remembered his loyal love and his faithfulness to the house of Israel. All [the] ends of the earth have seen the salvation<note: Or "victory"> of our God.
passages.98:4: Shout joyfully to Yahweh, all the earth. Be cheerful<note: Or "Burst forth"> and sing for joy and sing praises.
passages.98:5: Sing praises to Yahweh with lyre, with lyre and melodious sound.
passages.98:6: With trumpets and sound of horn, shout joyfully before the king, Yahweh.
passages.98:7: Let the sea with<note: Hebrew "and"> its fullness roar, [the] world and those who live in it.
passages.98:8: Let [the] rivers clap [their] hands. Let [the] hills sing joyfully together
passages.98:9: before Yahweh, for [he is] coming to judge the earth. He will judge [the] world with righteousness and [the] peoples with equity.
passages.99:1: Yahweh is king; let [the] peoples tremble. [He] sits enthroned<note: Or "dwells"> [between the] cherubim. Let the earth shake.
passages.99:2: Yahweh [is] great in Zion, and he [is] exalted over all the peoples.
passages.99:3: Let them praise your great and fearful name. He [is] holy.
passages.99:4: And [the] strength of [the] king loves justice.<note: The interpretation of this line is uncertain> You have established equity; you have executed justice and righteousness in Jacob.
passages.99:5: Exalt Yahweh our God, and worship at his footstool. He [is] holy.
passages.99:6: Moses and Aaron [were] among his priests; Samuel also [was] among [those who] called on his name. They called to Yahweh, and he answered them.
passages.99:7: He spoke to them in [the] pillar of cloud. They kept his testimonies and [the] statute he gave to them.
passages.99:8: O Yahweh our God, you answered them. You were a forgiving God to them, but an avenger of their [wrong] deeds.
passages.99:9: Exalt Yahweh our God, and worship at his holy mountain, for Yahweh our God [is] holy.
passages.100:title: A psalm of thanksgiving.<note: The Hebrew Bible counts the superscription as the first verse of the psalm>
passages.100:1: Shout in triumph to Yahweh, all the earth.
passages.100:2: Serve<note: Or "Worship"> Yahweh with joy; come into his presence with exultation.
passages.100:3: Know that Yahweh, he [is] God; he made us and we are his.<note: According to the reading tradition (Qere); the Kethib reads "and not we [ourselves]"> [We are] his people and the sheep of his pasture.
passages.100:4: Enter his gates with thanksgiving, his courts with praise. Give thanks to him; bless his name.
passages.100:5: For Yahweh [is] good; his loyal love is forever, and his faithfulness [is] {from generation to generation}.<note: Literally "unto a generation and a generation">
passages.101:title: Of David. A psalm.<note: The Hebrew Bible counts the superscription as the first verse of the psalm>
passages.101:1: I will sing of loyal love and justice; I will sing praises to you, O Yahweh.
passages.101:2: I will give attention to [the] way of integrity. When will you come to me? I will walk in the integrity of my heart in the midst of my house.
passages.101:3: I will not set before my eyes any wicked thing. I hate the work of those who fall away;<note: The term "those who fall away" is a rare noun. The verb from the same root is found in Psa 40:5(4)> it will not cling to me.
passages.101:4: A perverse heart will depart from me; I will not know evil.
passages.101:5: One who slanders his neighbor in secret, him I will destroy. [One] haughty of eyes and {arrogant}<note: Literally "wide"> of heart, him I will not endure.
passages.101:6: My eyes [will be] on [the] faithful of [the] land, that [they may] live with me. [He who] walks in [the] way of integrity, he shall minister to me.
passages.101:7: There will not live in the midst of my house a worker of deceit. One who speaks lies will not remain<note: Hebrew "be established"> before my eyes.
passages.101:8: {Each morning},<note: Literally "to the mornings"> I will destroy all [the] wicked of [the] land, cutting off from the city of Yahweh all evildoers.
passages.102:title: A prayer of [one] afflicted, when he grows faint and pours out his lament before Yahweh.<note: The Hebrew Bible counts the superscription as the first verse of the psalm; the English verse number is reduced by one>
passages.102:1: O Yahweh, hear my prayer, and let my cry for help come to you.
passages.102:2: Do not hide your face from me in [the] day [of] my trouble. Incline your ear to me. In the day I call, answer me quickly,
passages.102:3: for my days vanish in smoke, and my bones are charred like a hearth.
passages.102:4: My heart is struck like grass and withers. Indeed, I forget to eat<note: A rare homonym might yield "I am too wilted to eat"> my bread.
passages.102:5: Because of the sound of my groaning my bones<note: Hebrew "bone"> cling to my skin.<note: Hebrew "flesh">
passages.102:6: I am like an owl<note: The identity of the birds in this verse is uncertain> of [the] wilderness; I am like a little owl of [the] ruins.
passages.102:7: I lie awake and I am like a lone bird on a roof.
passages.102:8: All the day my enemies reproach me; those who mock me swear [oaths] against me.
passages.102:9: Indeed, I eat ashes like bread and mix my drink with tears<note: Hebrew "weeping">
passages.102:10: because of your indignation and anger, for you have picked me up and thrown me away.
passages.102:11: My days [are] like a lengthened shadow, and I wither like grass.
passages.102:12: But you, O Yahweh, abide<note: Or "sit enthroned"> forever, and your remembrance<note: Or "name"> {from generation to generation}.<note: Literally "to a generation and a generation">
passages.102:13: You rise up and take pity on Zion, because [it is] time to favor it, for [the] appointed time has come.
passages.102:14: Your servants take pleasure in her stones, and show favor to its dust.
passages.102:15: Then [the] nations will fear the name of Yahweh, and all the kings of the earth your glory.
passages.102:16: For Yahweh will rebuild Zion; he will appear in his glory.
passages.102:17: He will turn his attention to the prayer of the destitute and will not despise their prayer.
passages.102:18: Let this be written for [the] next generation, so that a people [yet] to be created may praise Yah,<note: A shortened form of "Yahweh">
passages.102:19: that he looked down from his holy height. Yahweh looked from heaven over [the] earth
passages.102:20: to hear [the] groaning of [the] prisoner, to liberate {those destined to die},<note: Hebrew "[the] sons of death">
passages.102:21: so that [they<note: That is, the generation that reads what is written> may] make known in Zion the name of Yahweh, and his praise in Jerusalem,
passages.102:22: when the peoples assemble, together with<note: Hebrew "and"> kingdoms, to serve Yahweh.
passages.102:23: He has broken my strength along the way; he has cut short my days.
passages.102:24: I say, "My God, do not carry me off from my life in the middle of my days." Your years [continue] throughout all generations.
passages.102:25: Long ago you laid the foundation of the earth, and [the] heavens [are] the work of your hands.
passages.102:26: They will perish, but you will endure. And like a garment they will all wear out, you will replace them like clothing, and they will be set aside.
passages.102:27: But you [are] the same, and your years do not end.
passages.102:28: The children of your servants will continue, and their {descendants}<note: Literally "seed"> will be established before you.
passages.103:title: Of David.<note: The Hebrew Bible counts the superscription as the first verse of the psalm>
passages.103:1: Bless Yahweh, O my soul, and all within me, [bless] his holy name.
passages.103:2: Bless Yahweh, O my soul, and do not forget all his benefits:
passages.103:3: who forgives all your iniquity, who heals all your diseases,
passages.103:4: who redeems your life from [the] pit, who crowns you with loyal love and mercies,
passages.103:5: who satisfies your life with good so that your youth is renewed like the eagle's.
passages.103:6: Yahweh does deeds of justice and judgments for all [who] are oppressed,
passages.103:7: [who] made known his ways to Moses, his deeds to the {people}<note: Literally "sons"> of Israel.
passages.103:8: Yahweh [is] compassionate and gracious, {slow to anger}<note: Literally "long of nostrils"> and abundant in loyal love.
passages.103:9: He does not dispute continually, nor keep [his anger] forever.
passages.103:10: He has not dealt with us according to our sins, nor repaid us according to our iniquities.
passages.103:11: For as [the] heavens are high above the earth, [so] his loyal love prevails over those who fear him.
passages.103:12: As far as east [is] from west, [so] he has removed far from us [the guilt of] our transgressions.
passages.103:13: As a father pities<note: Or "shows compassion to"> [his] children, [so] Yahweh pities<note: Or "shows compassion to"> those who fear him.
passages.103:14: For he knows our frame.<note: That is, how we are formed> He remembers that we [are] dust.
passages.103:15: As for man, his days [are] like the grass. As the flower of the field, so he blossoms.
passages.103:16: When [the] wind passes over it, it is no more, and its place knows it no longer.
passages.103:17: But the loyal love of Yahweh [is] from everlasting to everlasting on those who fear him, and his righteousness to [their] children's children,
passages.103:18: to those who keep his covenant and remember to do his precepts.
passages.103:19: Yahweh has established his throne in the heavens, and his kingdom rules over all.
passages.103:20: Bless Yahweh, you his angels, [you] mighty heroes who do his word by {obeying}<note: Literally "hearing"> the sound of his word.
passages.103:21: Bless Yahweh, all you his hosts, [you] his attendants who do his will.
passages.103:22: Bless Yahweh, all his works,<note: That is, created things> in all the places of his dominion. Bless Yahweh, O my soul.
passages.104:1: Bless Yahweh, O my soul. O Yahweh my God, you are very great. You clothe yourself [with] splendor and majesty,
passages.104:2: [you] who cover [yourself] with light as [with] a garment, who stretch out [the] heavens like a tent curtain,
passages.104:3: the one who sets beams in the waters [for] his upper chambers, who makes clouds his chariot, who rides<note: Hebrew "goes"> on [the] wings of [the] wind,
passages.104:4: who makes his messengers [the] winds, his attendants a flame of fire.
passages.104:5: He established [the] earth on her foundations, [so that] it will not be moved forever and ever.
passages.104:6: You covered it with [the] deep as with a garment. [The] waters stood above [the] mountains.
passages.104:7: At your rebuke they fled; at the sound of your thunder they ran off.
passages.104:8: They ascended [the] mountains [and] drained though the valleys to [the] place that you established<note: Or "appointed"> for them.
passages.104:9: You set a boundary that they may not cross over, [so that] they would not return to cover the earth.
passages.104:10: [You are] the one who sends forth springs into the valleys; they flow between [the] mountains.
passages.104:11: They give drink for every beast of [the] field. [The] wild donkeys {quench}<note: Literally "break"> their thirst.
passages.104:12: Along them the birds of the heavens abide. From among [the] branches they {sing}.<note: Literally "give voice">
passages.104:13: [You are the one who] {waters}<note: Literally "give drink"> [the] mountains from his upper chambers. The earth is full<note: Or "is sated"> with the fruit of your labors:
passages.104:14: [who] causes grass to grow for the cattle and herbs for the service of humankind, to bring forth food from the earth,
passages.104:15: and wine [that] makes glad [the] heart of man, so that [their] faces shine from oil, and bread [that] strengthens the heart of man.
passages.104:16: The trees of Yahweh drink their fill, the cedars of Lebanon that he planted,
passages.104:17: where birds make [their] nest. [The] stork [has] its home in [the] fir trees.
passages.104:18: The high mountains [are] for the wild goats; [the] cliffs [are] a refuge for the rock badgers.
passages.104:19: He made [the] moon for appointed times; [the] sun knows its [time for] setting.
passages.104:20: You make darkness, and it is night, when<note: Hebrew "in it"> all [the] animals of the forest creep about.
passages.104:21: The young lions [are] roaring for the prey and seeking their food from God.
passages.104:22: [When] the sun rises, they gather together and lie down in their dens.
passages.104:23: Humankind goes out to its work, and to its labor until evening.
passages.104:24: How many are your works, O Yahweh; all of them you have done in wisdom. The earth is full of your creatures.
passages.104:25: This [is] the great and {wide}<note: Literally "broad of hands"> sea, in which [are] moving animals without number, living things small and great.
passages.104:26: There [the] ships sail. Leviathan [is there] that you formed to play with.<note: For this construction meaning "to play with," see Job 40:29 (Eng: 41:5)>
passages.104:27: They all wait for you to give [them] their food {at the proper time}.<note: Literally "in its season">
passages.104:28: You give to them; they gather [it]. You open your hand, they are filled with [what is] good.
passages.104:29: You hide your face, they are terrified. You take away their breath, they die and return to their dust.
passages.104:30: You send forth your Spirit,<note: Or "breath"> they are created, and you renew the face of [the] ground.
passages.104:31: May the glory of Yahweh endure forever. May Yahweh be glad in his works,
passages.104:32: the one who looks at the earth and it quakes, and touches the mountains and they smoke.
passages.104:33: I will sing to Yahweh throughout my life; I will sing praise to my God while {I remain alive}.<note: Literally "while I am still">
passages.104:34: May my meditation be pleasing to him. I will be glad in Yahweh.
passages.104:35: Let sinners perish completely from the earth, and [the] wicked {not remain alive}.<note: Literally "they are not still"> Bless Yahweh, O my soul. Praise Yah.<note: Hebrew hallelujah>
passages.105:1: Give thanks to Yahweh; proclaim his name; make known his deeds among the peoples.
passages.105:2: Sing to him; sing praises concerning him; tell of all his wonderful works.
passages.105:3: Boast about his holy name. Let the heart of those who seek Yahweh rejoice.
passages.105:4: Make supplication to Yahweh and his might; seek his face continually.
passages.105:5: Remember his wonders that he has done, his signs and the judgments of his mouth,
passages.105:6: O offspring of Abraham his servant, [you] descendants<note: Or "children," or "sons"> of Jacob, his chosen ones.
passages.105:7: He [is] Yahweh our God; his judgments [are] in all the earth.
passages.105:8: He remembers his covenant forever, [the] word [that] he commanded for a thousand generations,
passages.105:9: that he made with Abraham, and by his oath [swore] to Isaac.
passages.105:10: He then confirmed it to Jacob as a statute, to Israel [as] an everlasting covenant,
passages.105:11: saying, "To you I will give the land of Canaan [as] the allotment [that is] your<note: Hebrew plural> inheritance."
passages.105:12: When they were {few in number}<note: Literally "men of number," that is, so few you could count them>-- a trifle--and [were] sojourners in it,
passages.105:13: and they wandered about {among the nations},<note: Literally "from people to people"> from [one] kingdom to another people,
passages.105:14: he allowed no one to oppress them, and he rebuked kings on account of them,
passages.105:15: "Do not touch my anointed ones, nor harm my prophets."
passages.105:16: Then he called for a famine upon the land; he broke every {supply}<note: Literally "staff"> of bread.
passages.105:17: He sent a man on ahead of them; Joseph was sold as a slave.
passages.105:18: They clamped<note: Hebrew "oppressed, hurt"> his feet in fetters.<note: Hebrew "fetter"> His neck<note: Hebrew nephesh can designate the life, soul, appetite, desire, or throat/neck.> went into irons.<note: Hebrew "iron">
passages.105:19: Until [the] time his word came about, the word of Yahweh tested<note: Or "refined"> him.
passages.105:20: [The] king sent and he freed him; [the] ruler of [the] peoples [sent] and let him loose.
passages.105:21: He made him lord of his house and ruler of all his possessions,
passages.105:22: to obligate<note: Hebrew "to bind, imprison" The LXX's "to instruct" presupposes ysr instead of 'sr, and might be correct in light of the parallelism that is fairly tight in this psalm> his officials {as he saw fit}<note: Literally "in his desire [soul]"> and teach his elders wisdom.
passages.105:23: Then Israel came [to] Egypt, and Jacob was a sojourner in the land of Ham.
passages.105:24: And he<note: That is, God> made his people very fruitful. He also made them<note: Hebrew "him"> stronger than their<note: Hebrew "his"> enemies.
passages.105:25: He turned their heart to hate his people, to deal deceitfully against his servants.
passages.105:26: He sent his servant Moses, together with Aaron whom he had chosen.
passages.105:27: They set before them the words concerning his signs and portents in the land of Ham.
passages.105:28: He sent darkness and made [it] dark, and they did not rebel against his words.
passages.105:29: He turned their waters into blood and it killed their fish.
passages.105:30: Their land swarmed with frogs, [even] in the chambers of their kings.
passages.105:31: He spoke, and there came flies [and] gnats throughout all their territory.<note: Hebrew "borders">
passages.105:32: He gave hail for their rains [and the] fire of lightning in their land.
passages.105:33: And he struck their vines and fig trees, and shattered the trees of their territory.
passages.105:34: He spoke and there came locusts and young locusts without number.
passages.105:35: And they ate up all [the] vegetation in their land, and they ate up the fruit of their ground.
passages.105:36: And he struck down all [the] firstborn in their land, [the] first of all their virility.
passages.105:37: Then he brought them out with silver and gold, and there was none among his tribes who stumbled.
passages.105:38: Egypt was glad when they departed, because the fear of them<note: That is, Israel> had fallen upon them.
passages.105:39: He spread out a cloud for a covering, and fire to give light at night.
passages.105:40: They<note: Hebrew "He"> asked, and he brought quail, and satisfied them with [the] bread of heaven.
passages.105:41: He opened [the] rock and waters flowed; they coursed<note: Or "surged"> through the dry places [like] a river.
passages.105:42: For he remembered his holy {promise};<note: Literally "word"> [he remembered] Abraham his servant.
passages.105:43: And [so] he brought out his people with joy, his chosen ones with rejoicing.
passages.105:44: And he gave to them [the] lands of [the] nations, and they inherited [the] labor of [the] peoples,
passages.105:45: so that they might observe his statutes, and keep his laws. Praise Yah.<note: Hebrew hallelujah>
passages.106:1: Praise Yah.<note: Hebrew hallelujah> Give thanks to Yahweh, for [he is] good, for his loyal love [is] forever.
passages.106:2: Who can utter the mighty deeds of Yahweh, [or] proclaim all his praise?
passages.106:3: Blessed are [those who] observe justice, [he who] does righteousness at all times.
passages.106:4: Remember me, O Yahweh, when [you show] favor to your people. Look after me when you deliver,
passages.106:5: that [I] may see the good [done] your chosen ones, to be glad in the joy of your nation, to glory together with your inheritance.
passages.106:6: We have sinned [along] with our ancestors.<note: Or "fathers"> We have committed iniquity; we have incurred guilt.
passages.106:7: Our ancestors<note: Or "fathers"> in Egypt did not understand your wonderful works. They did not remember your many acts of loyal love, and [so] they rebelled by [the] sea at {the Red Sea}.<note: Literally "sea of reed">
passages.106:8: Yet he saved them for the sake of his name, to make known his might.
passages.106:9: So he rebuked {the Red Sea},<note: Literally "sea of reed"> and it dried up, and he led them through the deep as [through] a desert.
passages.106:10: Thus he saved them from [the] hand of [the] hater and redeemed them from [the] hand of [the] enemy.
passages.106:11: But waters covered their adversaries; not one of them survived.
passages.106:12: Then they believed his words; they sang his praise.
passages.106:13: They quickly forgot his works; they did not wait for his counsel.
passages.106:14: And they {craved intensely}<note: Literally "craved a craving"> in the wilderness, and tested God in [the] desert.
passages.106:15: So he gave to them their request, but he sent leanness into their souls.<note: Hebrew "soul" or "inner self">
passages.106:16: And they were jealous of Moses in the camp, [and] of Aaron, the holy one of Yahweh.
passages.106:17: [The] earth opened and swallowed up Dathan, and it covered over the gang of Abiram.
passages.106:18: Also fire burned in their assembly; [the] flame devoured [the] wicked.
passages.106:19: They made a calf at Horeb and bowed down to a cast image.
passages.106:20: And [so] they exchanged their glory for an image of an ox that eats grass.
passages.106:21: They forgot God their Savior, who had done great things in Egypt,
passages.106:22: wonders in the land of Ham, awesome deeds by {the Red Sea}.<note: Literally "sea of reed">
passages.106:23: So he said he would exterminate them, had not Moses, his chosen one, stood in the breach before him, to reverse his wrath from destroying [them].
passages.106:24: Then they refused the desirable land; they did not believe his word,
passages.106:25: but grumbled in their tents. They did not obey the voice of Yahweh.
passages.106:26: So {he made an oath}<note: Literally "he lifted his hand," an act accompanying an oath> against them, to make them drop in the wilderness,
passages.106:27: and to disperse<note: Or "let drop"> their {descendants}<note: Literally "seed"> among the nations and to scatter them among the lands.
passages.106:28: They also attached themselves to Baal of Peor, and they ate sacrifices offered to [the] dead.<note: Hebrew "sacrifices of dead">
passages.106:29: Thus they provoked to anger by their deeds, and a plague broke out among them.
passages.106:30: Then Phinehas stood up and intervened, and [so] the plague was stopped,
passages.106:31: and it was reckoned to him as righteousness {throughout all generations}.<note: Literally "for a generation and a generation">
passages.106:32: They also angered [God] at the waters of Meribah, and it went badly for Moses on account of them,
passages.106:33: because they rebelled against his Spirit,<note: A slightly different verbal form yields "they embittered his spirit"> and he spoke thoughtlessly with his lips.
passages.106:34: They did not exterminate the peoples, as Yahweh had commanded them, <note: Hebrew "said to them">
passages.106:35: but they mingled with the nations and learned their works,
passages.106:36: and served their idols, which became<note: Hebrew "and they became"> a snare to them.
passages.106:37: They even sacrificed their sons and daughters to the demons,
passages.106:38: and they poured out innocent blood, the blood of their sons and daughters, whom they sacrificed to the idols of Canaan, and [so] the land was defiled with the blood.<note: Hebrew "bloods," that is, bloodshed>
passages.106:39: And they became unclean by their works, and were unfaithful in their deeds.
passages.106:40: So Yahweh's anger burned against his people, and he abhorred his inheritance.
passages.106:41: Then he gave them into [the] hand of [the] nations, and those who hated them ruled over them.
passages.106:42: And their enemies oppressed them, and they were subdued under their hand.
passages.106:43: Many times he delivered them, but they rebelled in their counsel, and were brought low by their iniquity.
passages.106:44: Yet he looked upon their distress when he heard their cry.
passages.106:45: And he remembered his covenant with them, and relented based on the abundance of his loyal love.
passages.106:46: And he {let them find compassion}<note: Literally "gave them to [have] mercies"> before all their captors.
passages.106:47: Save us, O Yahweh our God, and gather us from the nations, so that [we may] give thanks to your holy name [and] boast in your praise.
passages.106:48: Blessed [is] Yahweh, the God of Israel, from everlasting and to everlasting. And let all the people say, "Amen!" Praise Yah.<note: Hebrew hallelujah>
passages.107:1: Give thanks to Yahweh, for [he is] good, for his loyal love [is] forever.
passages.107:2: Let the redeemed of Yahweh declare<note: Hebrew "say"> [it], [those] whom he has redeemed from [the] hand of [the] enemy
passages.107:3: and gathered from [the] lands, from east and from west, from north and from south.<note: Hebrew "sea" (yam), which usually means "west" in a listing of directions. The word "south" is expected (Hebrew yamin). Either the MT was corrupted early (along with Isa 49:12; the LXX reads "sea" in both) or it looks to the bodies of waters to the south (see also the Targum)>
passages.107:4: They wandered in the wilderness, in a desert. They could find no way<note: The MT reads "way" with the previous line.> to a city to inhabit.
passages.107:5: Hungry and thirsty, their soul grew faint within them.
passages.107:6: Then they cried out to Yahweh in their trouble. He delivered them from their distresses
passages.107:7: and led them by a straight way to get to a city to inhabit.
passages.107:8: Let them give thanks to Yahweh for his loyal love, and his wonderful deeds for [the] children of humankind,
passages.107:9: for he satisfies [the] longing soul,<note: Thirst is perhaps in view> and [the] hungry soul he fills with good.
passages.107:10: [Those who] sat in darkness and gloom, prisoners of misery and iron--
passages.107:11: because they rebelled against the words of God and spurned the counsel of the Most High,
passages.107:12: he therefore humbled their heart with trouble. They stumbled and there was no helper.
passages.107:13: Then they called to Yahweh for help in their trouble; he saved them from their distresses.
passages.107:14: He brought them out of darkness and gloom, and tore off their bonds.
passages.107:15: Let them give thanks to Yahweh for his loyal love and his wonderful deeds for [the] children of humankind,
passages.107:16: for he shatters [the] doors of bronze, and cuts through [the] bars of iron.
passages.107:17: Fools, because of their rebellious way and their iniquities, were afflicted.
passages.107:18: Their soul abhorred all food, and they approached [the] gates of death.
passages.107:19: Then they called to Yahweh for help in their trouble. He saved them from their distresses.
passages.107:20: He sent his word and healed them, and he delivered [them] from their pits.<note: This word is only found elsewhere in Lam 4:20 with the sense of "traps">
passages.107:21: Let them give thanks to Yahweh for his loyal love, and his wonderful deeds for [the] children of humankind,
passages.107:22: and let them offer sacrifices of thanksgiving, and tell of his works with rejoicing.
passages.107:23: [Those who] went down to the sea into ships, doing business on [the] {high seas},<note: Literally "many waters">
passages.107:24: they saw the works of Yahweh, and his wonderful deeds in [the] deep.
passages.107:25: For he spoke and raised up a stormy wind, and it whipped up its waves.
passages.107:26: They rose to the heavens; they plunged to [the] depths. Their soul melted in their calamity.
passages.107:27: They reeled and staggered like a drunkard, and {they were at their wits' end}.<note: Literally "all their wisdom was swallowed up">
passages.107:28: Then they cried out to Yahweh in their trouble, and he brought them out of their distresses.
passages.107:29: He made [the] storm be still and their waves became calm.
passages.107:30: Then they were glad because they grew silent, so he guided them to their desired harbor.
passages.107:31: Let them give thanks to Yahweh for his loyal love and his wonderful deeds for [the] children of humankind,
passages.107:32: and let them exalt him in [the] congregation of [the] people, and praise him in [the] assembly of [the] elders.
